reviewText:
Hard to recommend a sequel to the highest rated metacritic rts of the 21st century, which changes (for the worse) and removes many of the original's features. From a singleplayer aspect, the ai is more intellegent this time round and provides more of a challenge. However the storyline is lacking and doesn't appear intwined very well from mission to mission. The theatre of war game modes add a nice change of pace to the standard gameplay, and lead to some nice co-operative scenarios, perhaps with inspiration from the Joint Operations mod for coh1. Again however, it isnt very well executed with some simply being skirmishes with slightly altered units depending on the timeframe.

Multiplayer matchmaking has also changed. Gone away with the lobby system, with just automatch left; this feels like such a step backwards. Removing of such core features leaves you with a small amount of customisation. You can create custom matches, but you will have to invite other players from steam to fill in the gaps. No longer can you tell whether you are competing with and against equally skilled players, with the new xp orentated level system which grants you xp for simply taking part (also accumulated in single player). No longer are there any statistics such as total online players, number of players searching as axis/soviets, how many are looking for 4v4s, 1v1s etc, leaving you feeling as though there are not many active players (percentages searching for a game jump erratically)

In game leaderboards are now gone, however have been instated in the Dec10th patch via a weblink. This feels really low effort and looks too much like an afterthought compared to the original coh1 leaderboards. I guess it is a good sign that Relic are listening to its customers as it was a highly requested feature by the community but should have been implemented into the game from release.

Gameplay wise, it hasn't been messed about with too much which is a good thing. Weather affects have been added such as blizzards which can cause your units to die from the cold, and mud which severely affects unit speed. The amount of units availiable to each army seems rather small which can limit your countering options and often leads to lack of variety on the battlefield; many players opting to use the same units because many are currently obsolete. Doctrines have been replaced with commanders which share many of the same abilities, meaning that your choice feels less centralised to one strategy; for good or bad. As with many modern games this leads to microtransactions. Commanders, skins and even faceplates are just some of the (rather overpriced) options available on the steam store. Why these are not available already to everyone, or just included in patches is poor and shows the direction in which this game is going.

To conclude; the main things that this game does well at, were already in place in the original game. Company of Heroes 2 takes away so much and yet adds so little. Adding the soviets as a playable faction in this sequel was nice, but was already done (very) well in the previous game via the Eastern Front mod. If you don't aready own the original (and its expansions) I thoroughly recommend you get that first. However if you've racked up 4digit hours playing the original like me, and you are itching for some more Company of Heroes, I can only suggest you don't pay full price. Honestly, I feel that this game is worth about a tenner, £15 max. Definitely hold out for sales on this.

2/5

reviewText: Really disappointed with this game. I loved the first 3 CoH games, but this one feels like they gutted it in order to create a lot of extra revenue with DLC. I don't have a problem with publishers trying to generate more revenue by tacking on DLC, but in this case it feels like they built the game, and then the bean counters came through and chopped out large chunks and set them aside for DLC. I suppose if I purchased all of the DLC it would be more enjoyable, but I'm not willing to pay all the extra money for sections of the game that should have been included from the start.\n\nI'm also not fond of the RPG element tacked on via the customization you can do with your Generals. I guess maybe it works out well for the PvP crowd but to me it's just a pain in the butt.

reviewText:
The game seem less like a step back, as some have said, as it is not a step forward. The graphics aren't overmuch improved and the extra detail almost makes the game look more muddy and nondescript. Think Battlefield 3 type 'realistic' pallete. This makes reading the screen harder than it was in the first game. For a RTS, being able to quickly observe and analyze the playing field is crucial. I often have to really study the screen a few seconds to figure it completely out. Also, the new engine seems less efficient than the CoH original and despite the relatively minor graphical upgrades the game is much more power hungry. Bring a powerful computer and video card to this firefight. With a AMD Phenom IIX4 and HD6850 l must turn the graphical options almost halfway down to get a solid 30 fps. The game was playable at maxed out settings but I found the frequent frame lag very upsetting.

Some have complained about the new implementation of doctrinal forces. I like them. You have a healthy number of commanders at the start with several unlockable as you progress in your rank. Others may be bought online for a somewhat immodest 4 dollars apiece. I haven't played any online opponents and I've heard complaints about certain DLC commanders being overpowered and upsetting gameplay balance. Just a caution.

Each commander has a handful of doctrinal options that vary between them. Some commanders share doctrinal options with perhaps only a couple differences between them. Some are starkly different. Having the option of choosing the commander at any time adds a nice touch of strategy as you can either get started early on the doctrinal options or hold out until you decipher your opponents strategy before locking in a choice. You are allowed to choose 3 commanders from your deck to carry in-game. This element is nice and makes for some fun fretting and fussing trying to figure out which ones suit your playstyle best.

The torrential blizzards that will ultimately kill your infantry if not in shelter or around a fire isn't as big an imposition as it sounds and actually adds yet another nice touch of strategy to the mix. Risking the lives of your men in a surprise blizzard assualt is one the enemy probably won't expect as it carries a large gamble on your side to get the drop on them.

In game physics and sound effects are stellar as ever. You'll feel the boom of explosions and the lumbering sound of tank treads crushing through the forest in high fidelity is a real treat to the experience.

To cut this short I will still heartily recommend this game since the price has dropped considerably down since release. If you owned and enjoyed the first game you will enjoy this. Just don't expect it to be leaps and bounds better. If not slightly worse for wear.

Thumbs up.

reviewText:
There are many things wrong with this game, just some are:-

The path finding is awful, if your units don't reverse towards the enemy they'll block anything else that has a shot. Before anything moves it rotates on its axis for a bit to make sure the AI can finish it off. The AI is pretty much god and can see everything on the map resulting in some awesome sniping with AT weapons. Snipers are pretty useless as everything seems to outrange them. Oh and sometimes when you click to perform an order it will simply deselect the unit, usually resulting in it being killed.

I find it impossible to play this wthout raging about how stupid it is, somehow it's just totally unenjoyable on every level. AI on easy is too dumb, but the next level up just cheats to such a degree to make the experience a chore. The AI cheats at everything, it'll do more damage, take less damage, move faster, produce faster, oh and gain veterancy just for walking around pretty much. I know cheating AI is nothing new but here it just feels like a lazy way to make the game difficult.

Throw in the fact you need to buy DLC to complete the game and I find it hard to see how the developers could have got it more wrong. No wonder the publisher went out of business.

With the amount of awesome stuff in this game to write about , i'm not even sure where to start! While i wait for a game to be found with the match making system , i can write a review until it sends me into my favourite mode (only) VP round. Compared to the first game , coh2 does not really do anything for me personally due to  the fact that DLC has killed it turning it into a pay to win , AI / pathing in this game also never cease to amaze me with such examples as your tank driving backwards towards an enemy making sure to expose its lovely ♥♥♥♥ to then completely ignore the main threat and shoot a single passing conscript.

Input lag is also more noticeable with some units remaining stationary as they burn to death and retreat at the last possible moment , most times they don't even retreat because ♥♥♥♥ it , it's -41 on the eastern front. I also do enjoy the moments of waiting whilst some guy lags out the entire game resulting in you being kicked , so prepare to watch units drive around in circles (if you are lucky) and die alot with the occasional good luck kick.

Campaign was nothing too great but wasn't bad either , can't really fault it , ToW is just the same thing over with different locations and scenarios and even that isn't good , a huge disappointment being the , Tiger Ace mission which is nothing  compared to the original.

Wrapping this up , i think most people who were avid Coh 1 players will find this game to be very poor and lacking. As most reviews point out , you might want to spend some cash to enjoy a game in all its single mode only Victory point fun.

reviewText:
The people complaining about DLCs are in fact just angry on principle. You don't actually NEED the DLCs. All the content the game comes with is easily enough to win in multiplayer. The DLCs do exactly what DLCs should - give you some more interesting options to play around with when you've played the living *#$% out of the rest of the game.

As for the gameplay, multiplayer is quite excellent, primarily because the factions are so interestingly balanced. Germans are by and large easier to play, but once you get to high levels of play, this is no longer an issue. Relic isn't perfect, some unit designs are bad (such as paratroopers), but overall the faction designs are deep and very interesting.

If you are so short sighted that you can't possibly enjoy anything that's not a carbon copy of CoH1 then nevermind. But CoH2 is groovy game. 8.5/10

reviewText:
Post-British update 04/10/15:

A solid faction to bring some variety to this stale game. Once the novelty wears off you realize the state of the multiplayer might be the worst it has ever been.

Basic functionality remains a mess. Game has been severely unoptimized since original release and post-expansion crashes are more frequent than before. Memory leak problems remain, micro-freezes/lag spikes unfixed (from 2-3 seconds every few minutes to up to 6 seconds now). Main menu capped at 30fps but sinks down to single digits after first game. During gameplay framerates are usually solid, but every now and then performance suddenly dies when loading into a new game.

Company of Heroes 2 is the UPlay of RTS games. Would you recommend UPlay to anyone ? No, I wouldn't either.

///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////

Grief, misery and frustration are some of the core elements present when dealing with the online experience in Company of Heroes 2. They do come without an additional price tag, unlike so many, many other things in this game.

CoH 2 is a prime example of the DLC craze.

This is the current breakdown of DLC content for the game:

Theater of War additional mission packs - 20€
Faceplates (cosmetic)                             - 8€
Vehicle camos (cosmetic)                       - 92€
DLC Commanders                                   - 59,5€

That is a base game of 35€ + an additional 179,5€ worth of possible DLC content.

Now of course, cosmetic stuff is a non-issue, but the DLC commanders include several important units, otherwise unavailable in the game (and more commanders are already on the way).

DLC and minor unit design annoyances aside, now a year after release, the game is still plagued with drophacking, sync-errors and constant p2p lag, turning wins into losses and once playful and happy kids into soulless empty vessels, longing for justice.

The familiar Company of Heroes gameplay experience is there with good sound design, decent visuals and ok maps, though leaving us wanting some great elements from vCoH like night and rain.

I can only recommend this game to the brave and most loyal CoH/RTS fans who can stay hopeful for the future and understand, that skill only gets you half way to victory.

reviewText:
I have owned this game for a few weeks now, and unless you can buy this at a significant discount ($15 or less), my recommendation is to NOT buy it.

Reasons:
- In addition to the $40 (or $80 for a version that already contains some DLC) for the game, they offer you all kinds of DLC (downloadable content) that should have been part of the game in the first place, and was released on the same day as the game itself. Lots of little extras that add up to more money than you paid for the original game. Some of them are useless and expensive (skins for $3 a pop), some give unfair advantages to players that are willing to pay to win.
- short, boring campaign that is Russians only. I bet there will be DLC to add a German and other Allied campaigns in the future
- in games where humans play vs. the computer, RELIC made the computer cheat in order to win. All kinds of treads on different discussion forums point to several ways that the computer cheats to win, making it extremely frustrating to play even in standard difficulty (which is the 2nd easiest of four levels available). Cheating includes advantages in resources, advantages in damage and hits taken by units, ignoring the fog of war, etc. It simply NOT FUN to play against the computer, since it will eventually overwhelm the human players. Every time. Without fail.
- even though this game got really good reviews from the professionals" (magazines

reviewText:
In the beginning there was balance:
Wehrmacht trusted their superior hardware to defeat their enemies and the Soviets kepth them in check with their cheap basic units and tough special units.
The balance updates were (usually) fair and the gameplay was fun.
But then came the first wave of strife: they added Oberkommando west and Americans.
The Oberkommando were fun with their fast vehicles, excelent infantry and brainnumbingly tough special units.
The Americans were not so lucky with their unspecialized infantry, weak vehicles and no heavy vechicles
Mighty Relic Entertainment desided to hepl the Americans by nerfing everyone else, making Americans more favourable faction.
Players were outraged by this for now Russians had no damage output and German units were too expencive to compete with the now OP Americans.
Relic didn't listen the pleads for balace update for their Sega overlords wanted all that sweet DLC money.
But Sega wasn't satisfied but the sales that the Ardennes Campaing and the new factions brougth them.
They wanted more, much more. Relic then made the Germans OP (for they were the most fun to play with) and the Allied community prayed a counter for their unstopable tanks and infantry. Relic answered those prayers by releasing the British: the faction with the superior defence structures and infantry.
After Sega was contempt with the newest DLC sales, Relic nerfed the British and the germans were once again OP (for they were the most popular with their fun equipment and good commander rosters)
Now there is only strife for Relic doesn't care for the community: they need more DLC to satisfy thei Sega overlords.
Maybe the game could be saved with a German Campaing or a proper balance update but for now it is buggy, badly balanced game with nothing that Men of War series can't do better.
Hopefully when Sega abandons this property it will be balanced like the first Coh currently is.

reviewText:
As a person who purchased this game's DIgital Collectors Version, played during the beta, and played the first game, I sincerely have to say that this game is a disgrace to both SEGA and Relic.

To start off, the beta was severely unbalanced. To be more specific, Germans had an edge with cheap and OP Panthers and Tigers storming the map easily. As the beta progressed, the severe balance was fixed however since then Germans have always had the upper edge in their versatility and superior units. Balance patches come slow and sometimes don't fix much, and most cause new problems. Along with this, the connection in multiplayer is often immensely unstable, so playing multiplayer is not reccomended, unless you want to play as germany(Which 70-90% of players are always searching as, so it is hard to find a game as them)

Second of all, the DLC. You will get royally hoodwinked if you buy the DCE, or this game at all. Relic Entertainment promised no pay2win and no game-changing content. They at first kept this promise, and gave the DCE buyers the skins and commanders. However, they soon started releasing overpriced commanders which had custom content, breaking their promise and creating severe pay2win issues more than once. They also did not give the new content to the DCE buyers, ripping them off by giving them useless content(commanders with no new things, skins, and cosmetic things) and then forced them to buy the pay2win content to enjoy the game.

Last of all, singleplayer. Singleplayer has been heavily critcized for it's immense unhistorical way of portarying the soviets; and many players were absolutely livid about this(check the metascore). The campaign tells a terrible story and portrays the soviets as people who kill everyone they meet, including half their own army. The ending doesn't make any sense either.

To conclude, all aspects of this game are complete rubbish and I fiercely do not reccomend buying this game.

reviewText:
Huge disappointment...

I am a big fan of the franchise but this watered down addition isn't worth its full price.

Campaign missions felt short and offer little to no replay value, with the exception of Tiger Hunting which I found to be the highlight of the campaign.

New multiplayer maps are dull and seem to be designed to serve the snow and blizzard mechanics; vast snowfields dotted with bonfires. It fails to compliment the original mechanic of how dynamic maps were meant to be, the beginning of your game could involve skirmishes between a maze of hedgerows and villages and end with battling out in smoldering ruins and craters. Steam workshop could redeem this with CoH 1 maps getting fan-made revivals.

The removal of the commander talent trees is what cripples the game most. No longer are the 3 distinct commander choices  that each serve their own playstyle and tactics but now DLC centered commanders that blend into eachother, the same off-map abilities and additional units rearranged and passed off as a seperate commander.The lack of commander variety will mean each game will start to feel like the last. Every game eventually leads to tanks vs tanks, grenadiers and conscripts end up serving no purpose but to rush enemy tanks, disable them with an anti-tank grenade the go capture a point while your tanks pick off the disabled enemy tank.

Theatre of War scenarios are a joke, they are simply AI skirmish matches. 1941 scenarios let you play with even FEWER units to choose from. Dont expect to see Stonewall or Panzerkrieg game modes from ToV, they'll probably be DLC down the road (hopefully steam workshop will beat them to it).

Company of Heroes 2 does not live up to its predecessor, fewer units, bland maps, mediocre campaign, and the biggest killer   is how the game is now entirely centered around DLC. I'm sad to see my favourite RTS get strangled by the DLC demon but steam workshop could be its salvation.

reviewText:
I will first start off by saying: Don't buy this game at the $10+ price.  Wait for it to be really cheap, by cheap I mean past the $10.00 count.

It's sad to see a sequel to a game take a turn for the worse.  With all the advertising going into it's launch, the public discussions from developers about the mechanics and unique game play and art.  All that pales in comparision to the majority of the games main feature: Multiplayer.

This is the frist time (and hopefully last time) I've ever heard of or seen an RTS game require pay to play in it's multiplayer function.  I have never heard of such a thing.  I expect the P2P from an MMO, that's understandable for server maintenance and other specs.  But to give P2P gamers an advantage over F2P gamers is not only an unfair advantage, it's an insult to both the game and the community.
I remember when Relic made amazing RTS style titles.  The most memorable for me were Home World, Home World 2, Dawn of War, Dawn of War: Darck Crusade and Warhammer 40,000: Fire Warrior.  As well as the original Company of Heroes 1.
So it truly breaks me heart and destroys my faith in a company that would take such an approach to their fans and the community for the multiplayer approach.

Aside from the unbalance approach of P2P vs F2P.  The units lack any proper A.I. responses to the heat of battle.  This involves, tank movement away from heavy fighting, moving troops away from grenades before they're thrown and the attack response time for squads when a target is sighted.

The Campaign itself follows the Russian point of view.  Playing out as a flash back.  I won't give any spoilers, but I was hoping for a bit more time in game play.

Now while the use of a snow and ice environment is a unique and well thought out tactic for the game, such as damaging lakes of ice, areas of belwo Zero to freeze troops and so on.  These fetures don't really make up for the major problems of the game itself.  While I admire Relic's attempt too try a fresh take on the U.I. it feels more complex and difficult to master, especially when in the heat of battle when you feel RUSHED to get something built or try using a squad ability.

Again I would say DO NOT BUY unless it drops beyond the $10 price range.
Instead look for the original COH and it's expansions.  Company of Heroes 2, sadly, does not live up to its predecessor.

reviewText:
237 hours in, time to finally write a review.
-More DLC content than base game
-There's literally DLC for DLC, I'm not joking. Buy a faction, they buy the commanders to use that faction's good units, then optional skins but I'm not even going to count those.
-You wanna get all the DLC? Over $100 and that's not counting skins.
-You want to hear more BS about DLC you need to buy the King Tickle DLC complaint DLC pack.
-Relic Entertainment bullies people who criticize their game, via deleting comments and banning on their official forums.
-Also emphasizes all positive comments... Relic? More like Reich Entertainment.
-Reich Entertainment barely even cares about the game, leaving the game unbalanced and censoring balance complaints until things get bad enough for them to finally fix something in a patch.
-Slight Axis bias. Yes, for the longest time and even a bit still now the Axis factions (Wehrmacht mainly) have had more utility and stronger units/abilities that give them the upper hand. Calls for balancing were of course censored by the glorious Reich Entertainment.
-Finally, the game itself is fairly lackluster in entertainment unless you have a group of friends to party up with. Online matchmaking can only last so long for the solo gamer and getting over ranked by the countless prestige 3 level 100s happens more often than not. Frustrating and lackluster sums it up nicely.

Conclusion: I've given up on the game other than private matches with friends for fun. If you want more info and less sardonicsm in a review I highly reccomend you check out Optimism's review, he breaks down the game more and is also one of the friends I party up with. Link to it here: http://steamcommunity.com/id/Sofakingwetaughtit/recommended/231430/

reviewText:
A worthy successor to Company of Heroes, the penultimate tactical RTS (after the Men of War series), that improves on unit variety, core mechanics, and graphics. Company of Heroes 2 is not a flawless release, suffering from early balance issues, but undoubtedly deserves the large amount of critical acclaim it has received.

Company of Heroes 2 releases with 2 factions, the Germans and the Soviets. Fans of the original will be comfortable with the teching paths, veterancy, unit selection, and gameplay mechanics. All of these have been tweaked in one way or another, but all are well crafted, mostly intuitive, and largely balanced.

Most welcome is the contiuance of directional cover and complex damage and accuracy mechanics from the original. Every bullet that leaves a rifle or tank shell that leaves a cannon has a complex series of calculations behind it that influence accuracy, penetration, and damage. A tank shell fired at another tank could miss, miss but still hit something, hit but not penetrate, hit and penetrate, or hit and penetrate with some critical damage. Everything from range, movement, cover, angle of armor, and more is included as variables in these calculations. These complex mechanics make Company of Heroes more than just a game of numbers, but a game of tactical placement of units and appropriate application of firepower that stresses the importance of flanking and misdirection.

In the end, Company of Heroes 2 is a game that released in solid form and has potential to grow even better in the months and years to come. The solid framework of the original was kept and improved upon, while the developers spent a substantial amount of time making the game beautiful in its violent craft. If Relic can continue making timely and moderately aggressive balance patches, this will be a highlight chapter in the RTS annals for years to come.

reviewText:
A grandiose waste of time and money. We have snow now, great. We have a completely messed up interface that leaves me as a COH 1 veteran dumbfounded. We also barely have any advances in graphics or gameplay compared to its predecessor.

But hey, I can buy a new style of menu border. Best idea ever. The campaign takes the very worst of Hollywood History and depicts the bloodiest conflict in human history in a way that seems oddly familiar to anyone who has played C&C Red Alert. Except that this game tries to take itself serious. With extra war crimes by evil commies thrown in for fun and profit. Don't expect the slightest hint of historical accuracy. Don't expect a halfway realistic simulation either, like COH 1 was at times. This is an utterly generic RTS with a WW2 setting, dumbed down for supposed mass appeal by ignorants who probably based their research on a handful of awful war movies.

Go and play COH 1 instead. Get a mod if you're bored. Avoid this game like the plague, you'll be happier.

reviewText:
Not realy your classic RTS formula, resources gather automatic no need for harvesting, but they can be increased by capturing points and building resource points. Units can reinforce if close to a reinforcement point, lil like the wh40k unit system. Besides that unit variety: a lot. Even more with custom mods. Campaign ya well, wish there was also a German campaign but overall it's decent. Additional campaign with Ardennes offence wich is also pretty decent.

Game can crash sometimes when loading the after match report but that doesnt happen too often. If you've played CoH1 then this one will not dissapoint, except maybe for the great ammount of dlc for sale (also mods for that lol).

Online players are usualy friendly and most of the time u will have an enjoyable match, of course u will also encounter the few unpleasant exceptions to that. Good thing also: theatre of war, custom missions that can be played solo or coop.

Only downside for me is the loot system wich is pretty much random play for 10 min or play for an hour, win or lose u never know when the loot is going to be coming your way.

Difficulty: easy (real easy) the ai doesnt even move unless you strike first, normal the ai only moves when you capture a point, hard the ai comes for all your base, and fast, expert u need to be faster then the ai with everything because otherwise f*ckin forget about it, u dead. So would say difficulty is well done.

Advice: vanilla (standard) is maybe  not the best experience but with some custom skins and tuning packs its well worth it.

reviewText:
I'm conflicted as whether to reccommend this game and I'll tell you why. The reason is that it's not as good as it's predecessor Company of Heroes.

The gameplay is solid, it's fun, it can get anger inducingly annoying but that's mostly due to human error. The maps are great, but not as great or as memorable as the Company of Heroes maps. I can name a dozen maps from CoH off the top of my head easily but when it comes to CoH2 I start to struggle. They're pretty generic and I feel it's because Relic couldn't just remake the old maps again and attempted to make new maps which were more generic and more samey than the CoH maps. The snow really grinds my gears, I avoid snow maps as I would the bubonic plague or mosquitos. They're anti fun and really dampen the mood during an intense game. The tanks however are improved I feel. The sides you can choose feel more balanced too. The new commander addition to the game isn't as good as the doctrine/company choice of the last game. They are all too similar whereas in the last game there were real differences such as the stark comparison between Airbone company and Ranger company. Each of those had their own strength and weakness and counter picking was a lot more important then. The online lobby is improved however I do miss one feature, the feature to tick up.

Overall, Company of Heroes 2 on its own is a good game and would be worth a purchase. However since CoH is cheaper and superior I can't reccomend it over that, and thus I've decided to not reccomend this game.

reviewText:
Having loved CoH the first version I thought I would take advantage of the free play weekend.

As many others may have done, we have eagerly awaited a sequel to what in many people’s minds was, and still is a brilliant game. Brilliant, I thought, I can try for CoH2 for free. Oddly I was reminded of the days of old when we would buy a PC magazine with a CD attached, we  could go home and install it, play the game demo, and away you go you would either want more or you would leave it. Anyway, I digress.

I downloaded the game etc etc. Clicked start and was immediately struck by the superficiality and lack of real depth. We are hit with a simple cinematic (perhaps this is a stripped Steam version I may need correction here) and bang we are in, no real atmosphere or scene was set in contrast to the quasi story personalised as in the original CoH. To immerse yourself fully you have to have some prior knowledge of this conflict to really appreciate the fundamental change in tactic that goes hand in hand that is required by the player to understand this expansion. In sum sacrifice is the mode of the day.  As another reviewer aptly summarises; the days of CoH allowing for an individual approach to gameplay such as defend, or inch by inch ground gains are gone in this release, hence the flavour of individual gameplay so loved in the original is overbearingly crushed by the mechanics of this expansion. Whilst trying to capture the spirit of expendability synonymous with the military approach of the time, little consideration was (supposedly) given to impact this may have on gameplay when transposing this approach to a RTS platform.

However, at $16.99 on steam free play weekend you would think it would be a steal, considering the relative time between its release and now right? Wrong, very wrong. Please do not get caught by this as it is as close to a legal scam as you will get. Yes, I mean DLC, and there is lots of it.

I'm sorry, even at the budget price of $17 there is no way I am touching this game, even with the deep affection I have for the first one. I really feel Sega and Relic are hoping to cash in on an emotional attachment that many of us have for the first game. One reviewer mentioned a bait and switch scam, which I have to agree with as that is what I might feel caught by if I buy into this DLC horror.

reviewText:
Not really worth the money. Graphics are good, but if you're into non-competitive gameplay, this is not the game for you. Ive been playing hundreds of hours CoH/OF/ToV, especially since the Blitzkrieg mod is available. So heres what really pisses me off about CoH2:
No Mod Support. They do have implemented Steam Workshop for missions, but the most important things they forgot. How are we supposed to enjoy beautifully built custom modifications like blitzkrieg or eastern front, when the developers work actively to prohibit such developments?
-DLCS: too many of them, with mostly no more content than a camo pattern or a commander. Those things are supposed to be in the game already, how can you possibly ask for more money?
-Maps are too small.
-Population cap is 100 only (unless it is on one of the workshop maps, if it is set in the map)
You want large fights, with multiple machine gun squads, assault troops, pioneers, field artillery and whole tank platoons simultaneously? not in this game.
-Diversity of Units: Panzer IV, Tiger. maybe a stug III. thats all you get when playing germans. with blitzkrieg there's different versions of the Panzer IV, Marders, Hetzers, Jagdpanzers, light Tanks like the Hotchkiss.
-Zoom: Like to zoom out to get a good overview over the battlefield? Not in this game
-Command trees / Skill trees: You like having the decision on what to get next to have the right thing for your next encounter. Well, heres the thing. The skill trees of CoH2 are just trunks - no branches. you get 5 or 6 abilities and/or units and thats it. and you get it in the order the developers intended to. You only decide which commander to choose. Do I need to cite Blitzkrieg mod again?
-Deadlyness of weapons: Can you imagine a machine gun shooting at a group of infantry right in front of it, in the open, and not killing any of them for 10 minutes? Hell, this game helps you out. You dont even have to imagine it, its right there. When you want to kill infantry´, use mortars or flame throwers. You dont need rifles, they do ♥♥♥♥. all of them.

But, there's something positive about this game:
-Possibly well balanced for esports leagues (I dont do esports, so who knows).
-WW2 Theme

reviewText:
Sickening how they turned this great franchise into a micro transaction pay to win mess...

The base game is still great. I love CoH more than any RTS. My entire problem is with the way they have turned CoH2 into a huge micro transaction pay to win game where the more you play the better your troops/guns/vehicles are.

So if you buy the base game you get several commanders. I can't remember specifics but the original armies from the first release gave you more options than the Western Front Armies. More commands. Six commanders for the Soviets because I bought the digital deluxe version and got ♥♥♥♥♥. Don't get me started on what I got for my extra $40. Six extra commanders and some vehicle textures, oh joy!

Anyway, it has been a long time since the beta testing and since I started playing retail. More on that a bit later. If I am not mistaken there will be three to six starter commanders for the Soviets (three of those are from the deluxe version I think), the German Wehrmacht came with three to six (again three extra from the Deluxe Edition I think), the Western Front Armies add-on came with three each for US Forces and the German Oberkommando West. I've logged one hundred hours of nothing but skirmish and online multiplayer. Though I tend to play skirmish mode mostly. At the end of the game you get random drops. Since purchase I have got ten Soviet commanders to drop. Nine Wehrmacht commanders. And one (yes, just one) US Forces commander to drop even though I have played mainly the US forces since the release of Western Front Armies.

The problem? When we beta tested you got to picked the commander and their combat options or perks so to speak. With the retail release you don't have that option and even though the two base armies have lots of commanders and intel bulletins that randomly drop at end game the commanders are too similar in my opinion. And the Intel Bulletins are basically improvements to your existing options. So the more you play the better your sqauds/guns/tanks are.

The add-on of the Western Forces gave very little. Random drops are almost non existant because they only have several extra commanders and they are trying to get you to buy them for $3.99 each. And there in lies the problem. Since Western Front Armies went live I have scored one commander and it was a cruel joke. His first perk is a WC51 Military Truck w/ .50 cal HMG mounted on the back that can't even pin down a squad of engineers. Not to mention they (any squad even engineers) can take it out so fast it is completely worthless on the battlefield. Does that sound balanced? Oh, but if I buy the other commanders they have much better options you say? No, thanks.

I recommend buying the entire game if you can get it on the cheap. I regret paying one hundred US dollars for the so called deluxe version. I have bought the Western Front Armies and the British Forces but grudgingly. Like I said I love CoH and since the original CoH I can't play other RTS games because they are just weak. I love the franchise and the game mechanics. I hate the way Sega screwed us loyal fans with this micro transaction BS.

reviewText:
Yes i still play this game, and probably will for a little while just because theres simply no real rts alternatives.  I do have over 200 hours into the game which shows that its got at least some appeal to it, but my overall experiance has left me swearing more often then not, and i have to acknowledge that the game really is a waste of time overall.

Unit response is so sluggish your units die unneccessarily (and seemingly wait until death is assured), units can magically go into 'miss mode' where you can have 5 tanks shooting at one that is at 5% health that doesnt die no matter how many shots are fired, or unit pathing that really seems to be doing its level best to get your units killed and goes anywhere but where you want, seems to go straight at the enemies needlessly, and exposes units backsides for no reason at all.  Tanks far too frequently need to stop completely and then completele their turns which has a tendency to get them killed.

edit: and with the new tank pathing its even worse, and this is honestly the most unresponsive rts (and maybe game of any kind) in history.  It simply doesnt take commands at certain points or does the worst thing it possibly could when it FINALLY does (like deciding to go in reverse everywhere, which was supposed to be the point of the fix, but they made it even worse somehow).  I wish i was exaggeratting but coh is simply record breaking in how bad units respond or their pathing.  It really unbelievable in scale.

Then there are only 2 factions, and those 2 factions are not balanced very well, and even if they were there are too many one shot kill weapons or things that can destroy your army in a single click which in my opinion goes against everything rts stands for as the enemy cant dodge this attack (see the aforementioned unit response sluggishness) and has no real defense against it except using cheese back on the enemy in turn.

Player stats and much statistics are limited to missing altogether, and they keep removing more information about other players with every patch.  Also this game is THE camping/turtling rts, which is widely regarded as the realm for noobs anyways.

Overall if your desperate for rts in this day and age and HAVE to have your fix and you can find this one sale for $5 then go for it, but overall its a pos and a monument to the failure of the modern video game industry.  Heck even coh 1 seemed like it had more going for it then this game, and you can find mods for it still and people to play against.

Oh and last but not least (altho not limited to, there are certainly other things to gripe about in this game) this is a borderline pay to win game.  If you dont have the pay commanders, prepare yourself to always be at a MAJOR disadvantage.

Really wish this wasnt the only real rts alternative today, and its a bit of a metaphor that relic went under after making it.  Honestly the more i play the i wonder why i havent uninstalled it yet, but a few  weeks later i will be missing standard rts.

reviewText:
Honest Company of Heroes 2 review
Cons and Pros of the game in short summary.

Pros:

-Awesome battles
-Destruct able battlefields
-Beautiful RTS game
-Nice progression in the gameplay from early to late game
-RNG risk/reward feeling
-Great multiplayer experience

Norms:

-WW2 elements
-War spoils
-Some unbalanced features for the different factions
-Less base building, and more focus on the battlefields
-Mediocre campaign

Cons

-Badly optimized
-30 Fps lock in Main Menu
-unpolished feels :´(
-No crafting/trading
-Lots of DLC
-Terrible ranking system
-No in game leaderboards
-Isn´t really big in the competitive genre
-Some clunky animations
-No options to change hotkeys than Classic or Grid

Quick Summary Version: The game is good

reviewText: It should've been an epic game. Was looking forward to it so much, I pre-ordered it. All the things Relic showed in trailers - weather, True-sight, cold-tec etc. looked quite nice and promising.\nAll the hype and hopes ended when Open beta started - it turned from Huge Hppe to Terrible disappointment very quickly - only two factions, mediocre graphics (it looks almost like CoH: ToV, but requires much much more from your PC) , dull maps (no cities, almost no bridges - looks like CoH 2 is afraid to be fun, not just regular e-sport-like strategy game)...\nIt turned even worse when game was released - never ending DLC packs, commanders, only doctrinal new units (you must buy commanders to get them). ____________________________________________________________________

The single player campaign games terrible insult to the memory of our ancestors, the winners of fascism. The most amazing thing is that the developers of anti-Soviet feces positioning game as historically accurate - it is a lie! This game is banned for sale in the territory of Russia and has one of the lowest ratings of users (1.8) on metacritic.
Due to poor sales, developers have moved to sales of air in the DLC (this complete squalor), and the balance in a multiplayer game is just awful, it's not to mention the bad graphics optimization and persistent problems in multiplayer.

reviewText:
After beta testing, throwing down a few hundred hours, being an idiot and investing in their 'DLC' (five bucks, but still...), I've come to the conclusion that this game, as painful as it is for me to say, is not for me.

There are far too many random events that decide the outcome of games... dice rolls that disable tanks, percentages that determine whether or not your grenades will affect infantry, among things.  Balance itself seems to swing wildly between patches, units exclusive to DLC, and the whims of the developers.

The UI is a number of steps backwards and in the wrong direction.  The UI designer himself was stubborn and refused to acknowledge the many, many problems associated with what he put out.  As a result, the final game suffers terribly.  The game was released with a number of basic functions not ready - an insult in and of itself, but because of the passion I had for the original Company of Heroes, and the unfortunate circumstances surrounding THQ, I was able to deal with it.  The UI eventually became, in my opinion, a whole new monster, as incremental updates were released and base features were more or less 'tacked on'.  The end result is an ugly, unintuitive mess that neither works or pleases.

Their community manager has mentioned that there have been near twenty updates as of this writing.  Their effort is commendable, but I do not see much in the way of actual improvement.  It looks to me as a series of lateral movements intended to improve, but in reality, the game is far to embroiled in poor design choices.  There are far too many variables to balance, too many nuances to control, and again, too many random occurences to feel like your personal skill was the main factor in victory.

By far the worst tragedy of this game is that the original went under and isn't getting the attention and care it deserves.

Review Update :

400 hours of game play later.  Also two years later. There are now leader boards.

Game was resembling something playable in August 2015.  This was more or less destroyed once the Brits were released in September.  The way that Relic abuses their player base is somewhat troubling.  A series of heavy nerfs followed the British faction over the next few months.  Relic slowly turned down the heat here and there but balance has truly suffered.

Game build is shaky.  Heavy memory leak performance loss after a handful of matches.  Latest patch (February 25th 2016) broke veterancy.  Not entirely sure what the direction of everything is.  We were told that an American unit (the Calliope) was having it's shots reduced from 24 to 18 because it was over performing, yet a unit was released simultaneously that can fire 30.  For five dollars.

If you can stomach the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t that this company shovels out, the game is still fun.  As a balanced, competitive game, I can't say that it is.

reviewText:
To be honest, its a terrible sequel. There are few things that CoH2 introduces that do make it feels like improvement, but overall it feels like its more of a one step forward, two steps backwards syndrome.

If there's one thing Relic(pre/during development) or Sega( this isnt the 1st rts that they screwed up) needs to learn and know, for the love of god, please let there be dedicated server for online matches. There's a reason(though not the main one) why most of relic games arent really relished by the online community, its the p2p system for matches, which makes the matches are ridiculously annoying and unfun to play with.

Comparing to its predecessor, games are surprisingly short. Probably too short. I think Relic may dabble too much into DoW2 series and forgot CoH mechanics when making CoH2. It lost the 'strategic feeling' of CoH, but doesnt really capture the 'tactical feeling' of DoW2. So what you get here is a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ love child of both.

The snow/blizzard system....its a gimmick. Is it good? Eh,... cant really say. I think Relic originally designed it to be a huge part of the campaign, it sure does wonder in the campaign. It does feel like winter in russia, which is freezing cold, chilling to the bone. But as a rts mechanic, I'd rather they do a working weather system, for all weather for multiplayer purposes.

If you are getting this game, you better have a good connection if you want to play online, or pray that your opponent does. If not, stick to AI matches, or play with friends. The campaign and other features are okey, but I'd rather play the predecessor.

reviewText:
The perfect game to play if you want to experience the joy of having infantrymen who are made of porcelain despite being in heavy cover, whereas your enemy is able to eat bullets for breakfast in an open field and live, happily murdering every single last one of you.

This would be fine if you had more men than him. You don't. Every single match I've played, the Germans have been able to outnumber me, even despite initial territory gains. They also get tanks before me because their huge doommobs of infantry and MGs are able to take every single point on the map, depriving me of fuel. And I wasn't charging across fields, either - I have had German grenadiers kill two squads of conscript infantry in heavy cover with every advantage available to them. This game just doesn't make any sense.

In fact, I tested this - I went and played a match versus a Standard AI, cranked out nothing but conscripts, captured every single bit of territory I could, and the Germans still had more men than I did in the early game and chewed me up and spat me out, given their units were more numerous and just plain better in every way.

I don't know what this game is smoking. Germans better than Russians at mass attacks? T-34s that cannot go head to head with the Panzer 4, not even slightly? What in Marx's name were they thinking?

TL;DR: The side balancing for this game is lopsided, makes no sense, and makes the entire game thoroughly and entirely unenjoyable compared to the first one. Give it a pass.

reviewText:
I really wanted to love this game but I feel that SEGA have ruined this as well as everything else they're involved with. There is an unbelievable amount of DLC for this full price game, most of which cost £1.50 each. Granted the majority of it is cosmetic, although personally I feel it's still too pricy, some of it does impact gameplay through commanders, which give you special abilities.

I'm a big fan of Relic and a bigger fan of the original Company Of Heroes, which I would reccomend over buying this any day. Don't get me wrong, this game does improve on some of the aspects of the original BUT THEY TOOK OUT BASE BUILDING WHY WOULD YOU DO THAT RELIC WHY. It really does hurt me to not reccomend this game as I want to support the devs but it's a huge dissapointment.

The 'expansion' is also incredibly overpriced for what it is. It's nothing compared to the expansions of the original game, which I would also recommend.

IN CONCLUSION, don't buy this game, buy the original and it's expansions instead.

*edited for seriousness

reviewText:
Company of Heroes 2 is worse than Company of Heroes 1 in every aspect of gameplay save for graphical fidelity, weather systems, the ability to hop fences, and vehicle reverse.

Company of Heroes 1 has more replayability, faction diversity, interesting player choices in the vein of tech pacing and it's doctrines, meaningful balanced asymmetry between the factions and their units, and perhaps most noteably, it succeeds in living up to it's name in every way, where as Company of Heroes 2 fails to deliver in it's demonization of the soviet union, and it's portrayal of every commanding officer being a monster with noredeeming qualities, and painting the infantryman of the USSR as cowards who would not fight if not for the gun at the back of their heads, despite the Wehrmacht killing their families and threatening to completely overrun their country.

Overall, it's this gamer's opinion that you should just buy Company of Heroes one, look into the excellent Blitzkrieg mod, and enjoy a game that is much, much better than Company of Heroes two.

reviewText:
I've been feeling that I bought an unfinished product of which I have to spend some more money to get it finished. The worst thing is that there are some achievements I cannot use since I don't have the right commander to use them because i don't buy the necessary dlc.

Also, gameplay is worse than i anticipated. You have to use same tactics in order to win and this is really annoying to me.

In addition to these I am having performance issues. Well, my computer is not top of the line super pc and it is 2 years old however I cannot understand why i7 processor with 8gb ram and 2gb graphic card computer so much slowed down with every video settings turned off. I updated my drivers as the game requested but no performance improvement happened. It looks really bad and on the top of that it feels like playing a slow motion game.

I am a big fan of CoH 1 and DoW 1&2, really good games in all aspects, however this game does not worth the money you have to spend so much. I cannot say this is a bad game, with a better computer it looks really good, but it does not worth all the money you spend because you need to buy dlcs for some cool units and for some stupid paintjobs.

reviewText:
Short Review:

Bad successor of the first game.
The first company of heroes had the main game and 2 Add-Ons, which could be played as stand alones.
Comapny of Heroes 2 however released a ton of DLc's and Add-Ons, making the game a money milking machine to gain maximum profit, instead of providing the best experience to its players.

You can buy extra skins, commanders, campaign packs, Armies, Perks...[the list goes on].
Many of which grant you quite an advantage above your enemy. (i.g. producing tanks in seconds, making it possible to spamm your enemy with tanks -> very easy tactic to win the game in early stage)

The variety of pay extra" parts make this game absolutely unenjoyable to me. While i got the game pretty early at which not so many addons were available i still got annoyed by the paywalls.

The new engine used for CoH 2 is imho worse than the original one and takes away a part of the feeling related with the series. The hp
date: aiming and pathfinding system is bad (applies only to you
recommended: not to AI) making the game feel sluggish and unfair when playing against AI opponents.\n\nOverall - not recommended. If you are looking for an arcadish 2nd World War Strategy Game
hoursPlayed: either go for Company of Heroes 1 (plus addons) or try out the a little bit more demanding Men of War series.\n\n5/10"

reviewText:
I normally play RTS games to comp stomp, one reason being that I know I'm not as amazing as the majority of players, so I like to fight the computers.

The main problem with comp-stomping on this game, is the fact that even on easy difficulty, they're so difficult it's not even fun, ever.

Now, I'm not going to say to make the AI like Command & Conquer easy, where the enemy turtles with the first five buildings available in the game, and probably send the weakest unit in a pitiful attempt to kill you once in a while, because that isn't fun, I agree.

But when you make it so damn difficult to beat an AI even on Easy and Standard, all the fun is completely drained, and you find yourself questioning why you wasted £15 or more on this game.

Coupled with the fact you have to pay for commanders, which most of which have the same skills multiple times, it's not like they're all unique ways of playing, makes me wonder, why couldn't of they just stuck with giving each side one of 3 preset command strategies?

I mean, seriously, what's the deal with that...?

THEN, to add insult to injury, they've gone and made the entire game just domination from most FPS's, let me state that I hate domination, I've always been a, 'it's not over till you've destroyed their last unit' kind of guy.  So, the fact I don't even have an option to do that, unless I make a friends only custom match just upsets me even more...

It's a shame really, because I enjoyed the first game, I also loved the way the British played differently to the other factions.  It completely fitted the way I played the game, with movable bases to help push forward where ever it was safe.  That's all gone, no way whatsoever of playing like that...

Also, the really good wave defence co-op mode from the first isn't here, which, if they had that, I would probably recommend this game, because I love to defend rather than go offensive.

It's a shame really, the game looked so promising, and Relic just failed to deliver what I, and probably quite a few of the playerbase wanted.

Just to clarify, if you're into the PvP part of the game, I can't comment on that, it's not really the part of the game I enjoy, I'm basing this being a casual RTS'er, who wants to waste a bit of time fighting a challenging AI, than to struggle and get frustrated everytime he plays.

reviewText:
So I thought I'd give this one a whirl, seeing as though it's free for the weekend & I loved COH1 and all the DLCs for it.

Game boots up fine, let's check gfx settings...hrm...really? That low?
Performance test: alright, although it doesn't look much better than COH1 it's definitely slower.

Anyway, keep default settings & onto the campaign. Nice story in intro video, yada yada, Stalingrad.

Tutorial-type 1st mission, first objectives OK, capture AT gun. Capture AT gun, I said. Capture the...now WTF?
It's a showstopping BUG.

My guys can't get over or around the teeny tiny sandbag wall in front of the gun and that's that for completing the mission. Throwing grenades at it doesn't help, just kills friendlies. There's no alternate route to the damn thing, either!

SCREW YOU. Uninstalling.

You want to play USSR vs. Germans in COH? Save your money and get the free Eastern Front mod for COH1 instead.

reviewText:
Definitely not a sequel. Obviously not an improvment on the original. Even simple comments like retreating a squad leaves them standing there as you click the retreat button and you watch the squad just stand there and get killed. Tank battles are impossible. By the time you have built a tank factory, you get rushed by 6-10 tanks. I was expecting a similar experience to the original, but it is not even close. Even the skirmish matches are laughable. I had all three flags at one point with 500 points and the enemy had no more than 3 sectors, but had enough resources to tank rush my base with 10-12 tanks, and legions of troops. I had them at 5 points, but because they smashed my base (with no resources), I lost !!

Most skirmishes last 20-30 minutes as you get overrun by the enemy. There is no balance at all. After 5 minutes of setting up your base, they appear on your doorstep with 3 tanks ?

Seems the developers put all their time and effort into DLC, skins and other features" that hold no interest to those that look for gameplay and realism. It is not a game any more. It has no depth and does not build on the legacy of the original. I should have kept my money and just played the original.

A real disappointment. Save your $ and stick with the original. At least his has gameplay and realism."

reviewText: Overall, the second installment of the COH series is a disappointment. The first game was such a classic. I felt it really revolutionized the genre of RTS, allowing for a unique gameplay. I'm not much for rushing/spamming strategies, so the original COH was a challenge, in that I was always pushing for resources, not allowing me to remain in my comfortable turtle" style of gameplay. It never felt overwhelming
hoursPlayed: like a pitched battle would.\n\nThe second edition has not changed all that much from that recipe. There are some neat whiz-bang things like cold
voteText: and ice

votesFunny: rather than selecting a squad and advancing to a location
commentsCount: I find myself micromanaging each squad. Sprinting from fire to fire to keep warm

column17: let alone forces spread across a map when a snowstorm blows in.\n\nAs far as balance is concerned
column18: Soviet conscript doctrine seems to be vastly overpowered. The ability to produce nearly 3 units in the timeframe makes playing as the Soviets far too easy and against them far too difficult
column19: on any setting. The Germans cannot keep up with the Soviet onslaught

column22: what the changes are affecting

column25: none of which do anything to help conceal my equipment and Soldiers?) and of little value.\n\nThe graphics appear to be exactly the same as the original COH
column26: though what can you honestly do with tiny little figures? I won't fault the maker for that.\n\nOverall
column27: I'm under the impression that Relic took a great game that was becoming a bit stale
column28: slapped a new face/ generals on it

column31: and ensured that anyone just coming into the Series will be thoroughly confused. Not worth the money I paid for it at all."

reviewText: What a shame. Somehow Relic thought it was a good idea to make Company of Heroes *more* difficult to play and introduce more unit micromanagement to players. Having to babysit an army of units across a lush and detailed battlefield left me feeling in awe of the war torn beauty but feeling completely overwhelmed when I lost entire squads because they were pointed in the wrong direction. Often there is so much happening that it just adds to the frustration and confusion when I'm trying to manage a battle of dozens of units. If you're obsessed with micro-management in RTS games then this will likely be your cup of tea but it just wasn't mine. Pass.

reviewText:
Company of Heroes 2 is the successor to the RTS Company of Hereos, and whilst I have played very little of that game and cannot judge which is better, I can still see the glaring differences. Company of Heroes 2 is not an RTS in the general sense; It has little base building, no worker management and a reliance on strategic points to gain resources. This system has turned many a person away from CoH 2 and Dawn of War II, Relic's other less RTS-like RTS, but are these things so bad? I'll discuss the pros and cons of CoH 2 and how well it draws it's mechanics from it's predecessors (CoH 1, DoW II and  DoW I).

I write this review targetting those who have already taken an interest in the game and are yet to decide whether to buy it, consider this piece as a more in depth description from an aspiring, competant 1v1 player.

The pros:- Company of Heroes 2 has good graphics: This is the least important feature of the game, it could look much worse and still be playable, but it's these graphics that immerse the player and let them believe they are in WW2.

- The game has improved mechanics: Ever been annoyed when your Predator tank turns around when trying to escape on 100hp and gets shot in rear armour? Well luckily Relic improved this from DoW II and added a reverse function to vehicles, allowing them to reverse over long distances instead of short, frantically mircroed distances. Another example is climable cover, meaning cover can be long and winding, with units able to move across it without taking ridiculous paths. Showing enemy setup arcs, very small but very good for planning an assault with.

- The range of units: Every faction has access to many units bought from base, ranging from mortar teams to riflemen squads to assault rifle armed Panzergrenadiers. This makes for the possibility of a wide variety of units employable right from base. But this is further augmented through the commander system, allowing for otherwise unavailable units to be deployed: Light AT Guards Rifle Infantry, Airdropping Paratroopers and fearsome Tiger tanks. The unit variety is excellent and makes for fun and fresh plays after many games.

- The commanders: Evolved from DoW II's hero selection system and CoH 1's doctrinal tech trees, CoH 2 changes this dynamic to make it more flexible on the battlefield. Able to pick from three commanders during a game allows for situations to unfold before deciding the best tactical move. Do you want one that swarms them with infantry? One that buffs your infantry and provides artillery support? Are you churning out vehicles and looking for commanders who can repair/send out the big tanks? Although it doesn't have the two path trees of COH 1, it offers more variety between games with extra doctrines that can be mixed and matched.

- Connection: The game allows users to reconnect to games if disconnected for whatever reason. This problem has plagued DoW II due to random drops and Steam disconnects which makes it a very useful feature.

Micro: This is not SC II and it's 300 actions per minute, you can sit back and evaluate your strategy, which makes it more tactical with less emphasis on micro and more in-depth combat.

The cons:- Optimisation: The term Relic lag" has not evolved within the playerbase for no reason. The game occasionally lags for varying lengths of time for no apparent reason

reviewText:
Purchased when it was on sale, otherwise I'd be furious...

The game itself seems alright, unfortunately I get about 4 FPS even with all settings down as far as they go and running at 1280 resolution. Many others have complained about the performance, and seeing as the game has been released awhile, this will not be fixed.

My machine should certainly be capable of running on at least minimal settings. Quad core, GTX260, 16 GB Ram, server grade SDD. Sega also lists the requirements as significantly below what I have.

TL;DR -- If you loved the first game and have a top top top end gaming machine, you will think this game is alright. If your  machine is anything less than the most elite, you will be disappointed with performance. I've read about users with machines newer than mine and still having to deal with single digit FPS.

reviewText:
So far, I can finally say that I've had my fairshare about this game. Yes it does have its faults, and what faults (hopefully) you may be asking?

Pros
+ The game has spectacular replay value
+ The game offers so much as for tatctics
+ The graphical Fidelity is BEUTIFUL
+ NOT intirely a pay-to-win process, more like TF2 and it's hats, you can find one just about every 2 months as a random drop, or you can go ahead and buy it in the in-game market. Same thing applies to Intel Bullitens and Commanders and Unit Skins.
I could go on, but at what cost....

Cons
- The game is very demanding in terms of Computer Hadrware, ranging from mass CPU usage, to requiring a pretty powerful GPU.
- To play beutifuly on the game, it is recommened that you have 16 GB of RAM, due to things, from the map it's self with the addon of dead and alive units, and Phisycs having to be rendered.
- This has to be a DLC King, reason being is that DLC's litter the place, Unit skins and skin packs, to commanders and their packs, to the Theater of War DLCs to the Factions/Armies.
- Low grade PCs will have anurisms trying to run this game for mid-game, early game.
- Your given two factions total win buying the base game, the Soviets and the Whermacht, the other three you have to buy in packs, $20 USD for 2 more Armis, including he $12 USD for the Bitish/Common Wealth? Strange times we live in.
Personally it's hard to choose a side for this game, I mean once you have all the DLCs, you feel content almost, or complete. With the additive to having those said DLCs, you have Variety for your gameplay!

I have a PC that can hand the game at Max Graphics, minus the antialiasing, which takes a huge chunk out of performance for an excellent picture, but by me having a PC that can handle this, I have no negative outlook on the game in the section of Frames (if I can even incude that).

Alass, I'll leave it up to you weather this game is fun or not, my 400 hours plus says something, but I'm on an unbalance sadly.

reviewText:
This game is a fantastic RTS, especially for anyone interested in World War 2. It was my first introduction to the COH franchise, and what a pleasant experience it has been-for the most part. Skip further down if you're only interested in why I'm not recommending this game.

Pros
+Setting and environments bring the battles to life, and the scenery (while pretty) is vital for your survival
+Interface is polished and easily maneuvered, even for new players
+Decent variety of units for each of the playable armies
+Wide selection of beautifully crafted historical maps
+Unit battles are satisfying and intense, especially between armored vehicles
+Quick-paced, dynamic gameplay forces you to think, strategize, and adapt
+Workshop is filled with incredible player-made content including skins, maps, decals, etc
+Overall incredible feel

Cons
-War spoil system is broken. Drops take hours, forcing players to purchase skins or commanders outright. It would take YEARS to get a good amount of spoil through actual gameplay. Relic is taking advantage of their players by intentionally monetizing the broken spoils system
-DLC prices are outrageous, as are the in-game customizations
-Unit movement and response can be frustrating at times
-Balance issues still unresolved

Despite how much I enjoy this game, and all of the time I've sunk into it, I would advise against buying it unless it's on discount. The war spoils are never going to be fixed, and although it seems rash to give COH2 a negative review based on that system, it's extremely disheartening (and annoying) to play 10 games in a row and not see a single drop. It undermines an otherwise quality game.

reviewText: COH2 is really not a bad game. The thing is that each faction has some advantage over the other. For example, OKW are extremely potent tank killers. US forces are much more mobile and much stronger than the standard infantry units, they are great for those that like being aggressive and maintaining continous pressure on the enemy. Russians are by nature a german infantry unit's worst nightmare, they are extremely capable when it comes to wiping squads: Katuskayas, B4's, 152mm arty, KV-8 flamethrower tanks, Shock Troops, t-34's that are still very good at running over troops, ISU-152's, IS-2's- the Russians are opposite of OKW: they are extremely effective infantry killers. Whermacht is a great defensive faction, the bunkers are versatile and if combined with mortars and paks, access to the surrounding territory is denied to the enemy. The British forces have extremely powerful units all around and bear firepower capable of completely disassembling any Tiger variant and never mind infantry. Also, every faction has many different commanders and abilities that are allow players to change the course of battles. Now with this all said, can this game ever reach a balanced state? The answer is it is impossible.\nRelic along with the other publishers have made such a versatile game with many different advantages that there is simply no way the game would reach this so called balance that players are so frivilously pleaing for. The W/L ration players have is ultimately left in our hands to change. Yes, the OKW leaderboard W ratio is very high and yes 4v4 would be a HELL of a lot better if OKW didn't have not 3 but 5 ranks of veterancy level and panzershecks. However, step out of 4v4 and play a 1v1 match and notice the difference, look at the gameplay, the striving to hold territory, maintaining units across the entire battlefield: 1v1 games plays like COH should. The problem is that in 4v4 everyone rushes and congregates around fuel, rushes tanks, and then gg. That isn't a game, and as I recall, the online ranked matches were about holding victory points, not fuel but this is what 4v4 games have become. Don't believe me, play the 4v4 map Steppes and watch where players go, they don't go to top where ammo and victory points are, they traditionally, almost instinctively, go to the bottom of the map where fuel is then work their way to top. Now not every game plays the same and not all my claims hold true in every circumstance, but just like the developers of Star Citizen in their efforts to create a persistent universe, Relic has made a persisent and ever changing stragetic game where no two battles are alike. A players best option: watch a few profressional COH2 1v1 matches on youtube and look at everything thats going on ,then step out 4v4 and try 1v1 or 2v2 games. It is the perhaps the best way to learn and become a better player in COH2.

reviewText:
First of all, I've played the orginial Company of Heroes a lot. I had around 200 hours into the original Company of Heroes game (not reflected in steam hours due to me having it played a pirated version with friends untill I finally bought the game a few years later on) which I've been playing from time to time on an amateur level for around 4 to 5 years. That being said, I'm just the average player in Company of Heroes.
Now, I have conflicting thoughts about Company of Heroes 2.

THE BAD:

- Poorly optimised:
This is a big issue, I'm running this game on an 2600k processor with a gtx770 graphics card aswell as having 16gb ddr3 of memory while the game is installed on an HDD, (TL:DR mid-tier pc). Loading times are crazy, even if you have this game stored on an SSD ,your opponent might not have done the same so you will still be forced to wait untill both of you have loaded in so that you can play. No, don't store this game on an SSD, not worth it.
The framerate is also terrible, I first played this game on 'recommended' settings and noticed my framerate going below 60 a lot. In the recommended settings everything was pretty much changed to normal, the game on normal settings looks even worse than the original CoH, literally. So I tried max settings, to see what it would look like. Strange enough after I've maxed out the game (a part from AA, set that on 2x) I surprisingly had a higher FPS, wait what? I don't know how much these devs have been jerking off at their office while they were just coding this game in general, but my cpu is always at 100% while my gpu is around 50%. This game, together with other games known for being poorly optimised only make my CPU bottleneck my GPU, it's not on my end.
Multiplayer games also stutter a lot, even if both ends have great connections. Not sure what's going on there either.

- User interface:
The user interface is one big mess, all sorts of icons of different colours and artstyles everywhere, they are not fitting together plus common usage of extremely ugly colours. I feel like they should completely redo the user interface.
The visual assistance in the maps also looks terrible when it comes to territory control, each flag has a circle around it with a colour which represents the player who's holding it, but it also has another outline which is where the border is when it comes to other flags. So you basically have reasonably large circle around the flag itself and also borderlines around. This makes it look like a complete mess, should have stuck with the orginal Company of Heroes design when it comes to that.
The minimap is also extremely bad, it's hard to find units on there. Needs to be redone.

- The DLC:
Not going to write a lot about this since it's already everywhere, the devs should stop releasing DLC with an overpriced tag to it. To me, the game is only worth it with all the DLC, otherwise it's just lacking units in general. So if you're only getting the basegame, you're going to have a boring time playing it. All the curent DLC should have been available since day-one or in updates.

- The Ardennes campaign:
No, you're an RTS game, not a rogue-like game. The Ardennes campaign is ridiculous, after you've lost enough missions it will prompt you with a screen saying FAILURE" and you will have to redo every single mission again
date: starting from the start. It's kind of hilarious how I started the campaign at the normal difficulty while the AI was definitely ranged above the hard AI setting. I recommend playing the campaign on easy
recommended:
even if you can beat the AI on normal and on hard (my case).

- Boosters
Now

reviewText:
What is Company of Heroes 2? A freaking mobile game?!

There are SO many high priced DLCs that feel as though they SHOULD have been in the base game. Only two base factions? One short campaign? A decently good multiplayer? Really?

The US Forces are DLC, a second Germany faction is DLC, the British are DLC, the US Forces campaign is a DLC... And they're not CHEAP DLC either. They're selling you DLC for full-game prices. So let me break this down for those who aren't catching on.


Multiplayer DLC
US Forces               $13
2nd German Army    $13
British                     $13

Campaign DLC
US Forces               $40
British next???

Expansions
US Forces Campaign, Single squad (FOX)
Several missions for the original game

Miscellanious DLC
TONS of skins for vehicles
TONS of perks that barely boost your performance (highest I've seen is a 3% increase)
Several different leaders (different special units and abilities)


You have to buy the US Forces TWICE! Once for their campaign, once to use them in multiplayer! Why?!?! The campaign is $40 as it is, and then you throw a $13 multiplayer charge on top of that? PLUS there's an expansion for the campaign that costs money as well? And it's only a new US Forces squad?

I really do not mind the use of DLC to expand the experience, but it really feels like I'm being ripped off by purchasing CoH2. Even though I got it on a great sale. I bought the sale bundle and got DLC that I can't even use without the US Forces Campaign DLC, which wasn't included in the DLC bundle. Seriously? So now I either buy a $40 DLC, or I live with the fact I bought DLC I literally cannot use.

In all honesty, I enjoyed CoH1 more anyway. There are a few improvements to CoH2, but not enough for me to justify telling anyone to buy CoH2 and ALL the DLCs being made.

Stick with CoH1. You'll get the full experience of CoH2, but at an affordable price. :)
