PROS=
Neat little true sight" adds a depth of realism and strategy to the mix of RTS. Cleverly placing a bunker in an alley facing outwards with a mg42 can trap soviet infantry real quick.
This is WWII and Coh baby and thus nice things happen. Things happen like hearing what sounds like a tank rolling around near by making you feel as if your that soldier. "Tiger!!!" lol. Or plowing a Tiger through a wall  and spooking the hell out your enemy. Sound is amazing especially if you have a sound system or a decent pair of headphones.
Now with the map builder theres an endless amount of maps and game modes available to you and honestly you dont have to touch it. Just hop on the Steam Workshop and Presto your looking at creative map from players like you and me.
I do like the variety of generals and the different supports they offer but... theres always a but.

Cons=
... I dislike that theres always one support you want that is not on the general you need. You cant pick and choose and you always have a support that you will not use or that is usless to your playstyle. There still seems to be glitches here and there. one of them that is quite annoying is the german mg42 will set up and not fire for some time. a couple seconds nothing to crazy but thats all it takes for soviet infantry to rush up and throw a molotov. Today I sat in a game and had to tell my pioneer squad to rapair my PZR4 5 times!!! NO!! i need that repaired like YESTERYEAR! Multiplayer. Multiplayer. Multiplayers nice. If you mind waiting for at least 10 min at times. Other than that its quite fun actually. The biggest problem though is within the ai itself and that is blamed on the creators. Im not going to lie I only play Germans since i picked up the game during beta. The last two updates have beefed up the soviets pretty good. Mortors now no longer need a scout. infantry spam is plentyfull and boy do they use it. molotovs are a cheap commodity and is also used. QUITE OFTEN! and i dont frown upon that. During WWII soviets had more than double the infantry compaed to the Germans. The only thing that differed though is training. Im pretty sure an MG42 team will mow down the hell out of 2 squads of soviet infantry thats 5 feet in front of them. but no soviets somehow have that finese to run straight up almost every time and toss that flaming bottle of love. The  harder you choose the ai the more it will cheat. I played regular dificulty and i could manage on my own and if i screwed up i can regain the map rather quickly. Now that is not true. Ill get infantry spammed
date: and before i get my first tank out the enemy will have 2 and plenty of support. ???? seriously! and its just the same with 2 players vs ai. Actually its worse because 2 tanks turns to 4 and infantry spamming and molotov spamming doubles. I like doubling coupons not molotovs or tanks grenades. -_- soviets had numbers and cold(and Vodka). Germans had training
recommended:
tactics and better tanks.

oh and yes DLC is a pain. Sure they need to make the money and all but theres a limit. The least you can do is offer everything to those who pre ordered way before to kickstart the funds. -_- greed is the fire that burns our soul.

Wait to buy this game when its at a lower price

"

reviewText: This game was extremely disappointing, as a huge fan of the first Company of Heroes. Being a fan of the First CoH and even taking part in the Fileplanet beta back in 2006 Company of Heroes 2 was everything that the word disappointed embodies. The game has no real content that sets it apart from the first one. The game play is not just banal when compared to the original title but when comparing it to other RTS that were inspired by this title. One thing I noticed early on was their was no WoW' moments and the AI seems to be worst. Digressing back to no "WoW" moments. In the original CoH  when playing a hard long fought out match or maybe even early game and someone uses a smart flank or tactic that you over looked or didn't expect
date: maybe someone builds or calls in a unit that makes both teams have that "wow"moment. Those moments that causes both teams to be re-energize. Sending both teams on a emotion rollercoaster to hold or defend or revamp or rethink an attack or withdraw or maybe a full retreat of a area they have held the whole game. If you're looking for that then this is not the game for you. I would recommend the original CoH and or just the stand alone expanation packs."

reviewText:
An excellent Sequel to an Excellent RTS.

It refines on the gameplay of the previous game while adding in new elements like truesight and vaulting which at first sight may seem minimal in effect but as you play the game reveal themselves to have a much greater impact and offer a great deal of tactical options.

The Campaign is fun. Nice and long. But it does suffer a bit in my opinion from the fact that it tries to cover the entire thing from Barbarossa to Berlin and ends up being a bit unfocused. Personally think it would have benefitted much from focusing on a single event like Operation Bagration.

Multiplayer as always is a tricky thing in regards to balance as things generally change as new ideas are mixed in. Was with CoH and so it is with CoH2. But overall balance is great there's always an option for a clever player and generally i don't feel like you're shoe-horned into a specific response.

So overall. A most recommendable game and a must play if you were to ask me.

reviewText:
In short: Buy the Original.

I wanted to like this game, I really did. I love the first one, it's well balanced, tactical and not just Age of Empires without the resource gathering. Oh and yeah it has no micro transactions. COH 2 is simply a case of whoever has the most infantry wins untill tanks come along and then who has the most tanks win. However thing is you don't get access to the full tech tree, you only get access to certain units past the basic 7 or so, to get access to more you unlock with your commanders of which you only can have one per match. Like the first game right? Nope. In this game there are heaps of them and you get three commanders at the start for free, (which you don't choose) and they give you a couple of units, every other one you have to buy with real world dollars unless you get lucky and get them as a reward and of course these are the ones with fun and powerful units. Want a KV flame tank? That will be $6, a Pershing? Another 6, want British Engineers who can salvage scraps? Time to get the credit card out and pay some more.

So basically if you like pay to win micro transactions, spamming infantry in a numbers game then this game is for you. Otherwise buy the first one.

reviewText:
This game gives me mixed feelings. The community is great but the developers Relic couldn't care less.

So first, the positive things. The game is RTS and it provides nice graphics, four factions (DLC for two more) and a lot of decent maps.

Balance is usually an issue with RTS games where you have different factions. So is the case for COH2 as well.

Relic Entertainment also managed to neglect fixing obvious bugs in the game and focus on releasing Adriennes (single player campaign) that VERY FEW of the COH2 community will enjoy.

TLDR; Game has bugs, dev knows but doesn't fix them. Dev release DLCs instead of fixing bugs. Standard reply by Relic is We constantly work with fixing bugs and will to everything we can to fix them". Still nothing happens."

reviewText:
This is an excellent successor to the original COH. COH2 is a world war 2 RTS game where you capture control points to get fuel, munitions, and manpower. You can play as different ww2 factions which have different units and strategies. If you've ever had any interest in WW2, you owe it to yourself to play this game.

The multiplayer is a very strong part of this game and I found it to be enjoyable. It's especially fun to team up with a friend against other people and have a good time. There is both a serious part of the multiplayer ladder and a casual part, so every skill level does well.

My one complaint about this game is the pay to win commander selection. Commanders dictate which special abilities you get (for instance a special tank call in or an air strike). Some of the commanders you get by paying for them or being very very lucky and getting them in a drop.

reviewText: Despite the terrible state of the game at launch; this game has seen vast improvements and polishing. Many new maps and commanders have been added into the game, which was the main problem at the launch of Company of Heroes 2. But on the other hand, the adding of all this content has created quite an imbalance. It seems soviet players are at a bit of a disadvantage. At the rate the developers are working on the game, I definately know this is going to be finally fixed and polished, so everything works out well. With the addition of western fronts, the game might actually become a worthy sucessor to its prodecessor, Company of Heroes. Which, is arguably one of the best RTS games ever made. After playing around as much as I have with the game since launch, I definitely recommend Company of Heroes 2.

reviewText:
For my blog http://gamoha.eu I wrote an article in German about Company of Heroes 2: The Western Front Armies. I will sum up the results of our review and like to invite you to visit our blog:

Company of Heroes 2: The Western Front Armies is a well done Standalone-Addon. The developers have created the game with great attention to details and the game will provide a high fun factor for experiences and new players. It challenges for individuals and team players alike, even though you can lose overview to the battle very quickly.  Another argument buying the game is that you can play together with other players who only got the retail version. New player will need a little more time to discover the various style of using units and their abilities. The combination of units which is a key element of the Company of Heroes games will need practise and experience. For the future we would like to have better balancing of all fractions and additional content.

If you like to read the review in detail you can visit our German blog:
German Version http://gamoha.eu/testbericht-company-of-heroes-2-twfa/
English Version http://gamoha.eu/review-company-of-heroes-twfa/

reviewText:
Want to win more? Buy some commanders.

Want to have a full and fair game experience? You're gonna have to pay for it.

Want a bug-free, polished and immersive experience? You came to the wrong place, mate.

Players should not have to spend huge amounts of money on DLC in the vain hope of fixing a game that should never have been broken in the first place.

Probably, many of those who purchased DLC simply could not bear another minute of the disgustingly in-your-face advertising and constant prompts to pay for full access to the game that they had already paid for that they gave in and handed over more cash to make the pain go away.

The commercialisation of this game is sickening and goes to show just how cynical, greedy and contemptful of gamers SEGA, and the big publishers really have become.

SEGA may not have dealt a death-blow to Company of Heroes, but with CoH2 they've left it curled in the fetal position begging for mercy.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------

Full Review:

Company of Heroes was easily one of the best RTS games produced in recent years. The gritty gameplay, steep learning curve and atmosphere that Relic created in CoH:1 through the wartorn environments and spot on audio made for an impressively immersive experience. Tactical decisions felt utterly crucial at every moment, and it was easy to vicariously feel the terror and exuberation of your soldiers as they pushed through enemy lines or faced certain, crushing death.

In CoH:2 the game has had a facelift and along with the addition of new vehicles, units and armies the scope of the franchise is greater than ever before. The addition of the Soviet forces was a much-needed expansion to the game's world, story, and gameplay and the developers have obviously set out with a clear vision to extend the legacy of CoH:1.

Sadly, however, CoH2 is neither the sequel that CoH1 deserved nor the sequel that fans of the series deserved.

The graphics have indeed been improved, but stunning artistic vision and attention to detail count for nought when a game's optimisation is mediocre at best. Expect janky performance when in the middle of a fierce battle unless you're playing on a remarkably powerful rig. It's not game-breaking, but it undermines the immersive fluidity that is so key to any RTS and which Relic did so well on in CoH1.

Similarly, while the audio is as lush as ever to listen to, I've nonetheless experienced ridiculous mistimings. On several occasions battle music has started playing long after the firefight was well and truly over. Poor audio cues like this again undermine the immersive experience that made CoH1 and should have made CoH2 great.

However, the greatest tragedy and travesty of CoH2 is the complete in-your-face, buy-buy-buy, spoon-feeding of DLC at every available opportunity. I loaded the game up for the first time in anticipation of a solid sequel and eager to see the changes from CoH1 only to discover that the most prominent change was a massive banner advertisement and constant prompts telling me that I should drop more cash on the game I had already paid for.

Frankly, the over-commercialisation of this game is sickening.

Sure, it's not straight up pay to win, but you can't deny that having more commanders and armies provides players who choose to pay extra for them with far greater tactical flexibility and thus opportunity (at least) to win. Commander choice is not determinative of victory, but it can go a long way. This is especially true when a DLC-purchaser knows you only have access to the standard commanders and they can therefore plan to utterly steamroll you with the commander they paid 12 bucks for.  The uneven playing field which the developers have intentionally created to make money off of feels profoundly unjust.

This is especially true because of the nature of the RTS genre. I enjoy RTS games for the same reason I enjoy playing chess, cards or any other such game with friends, because it provides a chance to directly put your mental mettles to the test. The tendency towards pay to win in this game undermines that chance for a fair fight. I expect this from mediocre shooters, not from big name RTS franchises.

Don't get me wrong, there's nothing wrong with releasing solid amounts of DLC for games where time and thought is put into them and (most importantly!) they don't undermine the experience of the game for players who exclusively own the core game. The problem is that on both these counts, and spectacularly on the latter, CoH2 is a failure.

I can't speak for everyone else, but there's only so much callously in your face DLC-pushing that I can handle before I end up walking away from a game starting to feel sick in my mouth. This is not what I expected, wanted, or deserved from CoH2. It should not cost hundreds of dollars after the fact to have full and fair access to the contents of an RTS game.

Sure, you could choose to sink a few hours into this game and you probably wouldn't have an awful time. It still looks and sounds good, and the core gameplay is solid enough. There are even some neat additions. But the fresh lick of paint that might have tricked you into thinking you just bought a mint new Porsche is going to quickly peel away to reveal the rusty 1976 Skoda shitwagon that SEGA have buried beneath.

If you buy this game you're effectively lining the pockets of skeezy corporate salesmen who don't care about the consumer and just want to make a quick buck by spamming us with intrusive, underwhelming and game-ruining DLC. Don't fall for their tricks. Do not buy Company of Heroes 2.

reviewText: Company of Heroes 2 comes off strong with its new campaign, and it packs an impressive amount of extra features. Standing on its own, it is an impressive real-time strategy game, but there are people who want to know what makes this better than the beloved original Company of Heroes. The simple answer to that question is that it's more of what they love.The sequel brings a new campaign, new multiplayer maps and units, new co-op modes, more explosions, more units on the field, and deathly winter combat, all presented with the gameplay that made the first such a hit. It stays true to its roots while bringing in enough new, compelling content to make it worthwhile.The sequel to one of the best strategy titles out there, Company of Heroes 2 lives up to its predecessor. The game focuses on the Eastern front of World War II, and during the campaign the player takes on the role of the Russians. It's a slow-paced RTS, with a big emphasis placed on unit placement and having troops stay behind cover if they want to survive.The utterly fantastic campaign is among the best I have played in a strategy game. Missions are varied enough that different tactics have to be used to win each one. There are some defense missions that are so hectic I had to constantly readjust my troops to face new attacks coming from all sides. One mission takes place in the snow, and you have to prevent your troops from freezing to death by moving close to fires, or keeping them inside.Another one of my favorites involved hunting down and destroying a Tiger tank, which I ultimately accomplished by luring it into a series of mines I placed as a trap. There are 14 missions in the campaign, and each one takes between 20-60 minutes to complete depending on the difficulty and how terrible you are at playing.All of the new mechanics fit well with the Eastern Front setting. Lots of soldiers will die, and CoH2 does a brilliant job of making it expensive to lose troops.Taking over an enemy territory will certainly require you to sacrifice a lot of men, and sometimes you'll have to do it knowing you won't be able to replace them easily.I was always faced with some form of a choice with each unit. Do I have them run in and face certain death
date: or do I hold back and wait for a better opportunity?" Better opportunities don't always come

reviewText:
Summary:
[+] This game is a wonderful one. It's fun, has a lot of small things to take into account and a great variation depending on which team you play. The small things matter which is always lovely in a strategy based game. Many maps and a hell of a war-feeling to it.

[-] However, the current state of the Matchmaking system, is seriously broken and will put you up against people with 10-20 times the in-game hours you've got.

Verdict: Don't buy this game unless you're prepared to spend numerous (hundreds) hours playing against bots. Because the MM will show you just how bad you are at the game and you won't get a chance to turn the games around or understand what you did wrong, because the good players are so beyond your level of play that you'll be a bleeding kitten swimming in a pool of hungry piranhas.

------------------------------------------------------------------

At the moment I've invested 31 hours into this game. I played CoH back in the day and had a lot of hours and know the game mechanics fairly well. When me and a friend (40 hours played) search for matches, we get matched with people who've prestiged one, two and sometimes even three times.

How can they claim the MM-system is a working one?
I have yet to have a game with people at the same skill level as me. At the same time they claim that the MM-system actually is fair and should match you against players at the same level as yourself.
How come it doesn't then?

I see a lot of posts on the internet regarding this, some people (good at the game, many hours) defend this, because if they get matched with a good player(s) they will have a chance because of their skill level. Many people (mostly not so good, few hours) are complaining they simply can't use MM at all because of the uneven matchmaking that currently rules the games.

I will lose interest in this game way before I reach that level. It's simply to challenging and not fun to be matched up against players with 700+ hours. At the same time it's not realistic that a game forces you to play 200 hours against bots before you can even try to make a difference in 2v2, 3v3, 4v4.

The 1v1 is pretty much 50/50. Sometimes you get a player closer to your skill level, sometimes you get one with a hell of a lot more time invested than yourself.

I'm sick of this and I have yet to find a post from developers that take this criticism seriously, no matter how constructive it might be.

I'm sad to give this a bad review as I love the game, the feel and everything around it. The MM-system is what's broken and has to be fixed. I rather stay in a queue for 25-30 minutes than get matched after 5-10 against opponents who will stomp with ease.

reviewText:
Company of Heroes 2 is the natural evolution of the best RTS in the last decade that Relic Entertainment has made. This game adds enough to feel like a true sequel as well as maintain the Company of Heroes vibe all of us RTS junkies love. The production value is high, the dynmanic way the multiplayer matches play out makes the game always exciting and interesting. Each match feels different.

The single player is engaging and tells an excellent story about the dark side of the Red Army while showing there were alot of good men and women who fought bravely to stop the Nazi domination of their country. The graphics look fantastic, the sound design is top notch and really immerses you in the game.

There in addition to the Campaign and Multiplayer aspect is the Theater of War mode, which adds fun challanges, which are solo and some are coop to play with friends. This feature is hoped to expand across the entire war, as of now it is only Early war which is proving incredibly difficult and nearly impossible on General difficulty but Pounder and I just suck lol.

This game is a great run for youre money. It has some well thought out features. Twitch integration for people who want to try out streaming their game, but have no experiance or money to pay for Xsplit or don't want to fuddle around with OBS software to stream. It makes things simple and fun to stream.

There is an excellent road map with up to a year or more content planned and expanded for the game. New commanders, New Maps, New cammo patterns for youre tanks and units, A fully secure Ladder is promised for multiplayer in the near future, as well as Observer mode for us shoutcasters!!

Pick COH2 up if you even remotely like Real Time strategy or the Second World War.

reviewText:
Relic really out did themselves with this one, CoH2 has greatly improved on the base that was set by the original CoH, there are subtle visual improvements and numerous hit-or-miss gameplay tweaks as the series moved focus from the West to the East.

Of course the original CoH has held up remarkably well too. (if you havent played it, I absolutely recommend you do) The Campaign of CoH2 is great but the games true strength lays in its multiplayer and its great workshop support meaning there is never a shortage of maps to play on.

As more and more games move into a modern focus its refreshing to play a WWII game, even more so when it isn't just about America and England vs Germany, this is all about the great patriotic war the Soviet Union waged against the Nazis.

Great game, great rts, worth owning

(Like all my reviews I do not put a score as it is my belief that games like all forms of art are subjective and therefore it is impossible to afix a number to them)

reviewText:
I really loved COH and I also like COH 2 despite it's weaknesses.

First of all, the game has great graphics and game mechanics. Especially on 4v4 MP matches this games become great on the endgame when you have tank battles like in kursk and you fight for every point as your tickets amount become low. You then face a sometimes little disturbing battles where many soldiers die for holding this point and you realise how hard war can be when a single salve of artillery fire kills 20 of your brave elite soldierts who did everything to follow your order.

The singleplayer is also nice and I really wish they had spent more effort German and allied campaigns.

Pros:

+ Great RTS with many options and ways to achieve victory
+ Cool mechanics and graphics

reviewText:
Total garbage.

Game supposed to be realistic and is so far from it....  the glitch is great too.

Company of Heroes 1 is a legendary game.

This is an atrocity.  And a cash grab.

Everything about COH 1 was perfect.  This game is little portions of content for a lot of money and everything else cut out of it and in separate, smaller packages to just ♥♥♥♥ you of even more money.  I will never buy from these developers or publishers again.  I boycott them now like I and my friends boycott EA and anything coming out of them.

Game is literally, a blob fest.  Race for tanks.  Everything else in this game is not worth the resources.

All units are watered down.  Infantry is a joke; it's pointless.  The trees in all armies are TERRIBLE.  Not even fun like the first one.  There is no strategy in this except to blob.

The maps are hideous and no time was put into any of them.  They're all similar.

Just someone going through and placing down buildings and brush totally at random.  Go look at COH 1 maps and look at any of these.  There is a massive difference.  All COH 2 maps resemble each other and there's no rhyme or reason to any of them, just cheaply done.

Most maps are cut out and purchasble as additional content.  Like any decent commanders.

The game is also set up that if you want to win scenarios you're going to have to buy the better commanders with the better content.  The ones provided are pretty useless and weak.

Commander abilities are nothing special either like the first COH, just junk and shared across each other.

Tanks are the game.  If you like tank spam guy this piece of total garbage.

Thievery at it's best.

Publisher and Devs now boycotted.

Never, ever see another dime out of me or anyone I know who's played this.

They all had the same opinion and they played it before me.  I did buy a lot of content and spend a lot of time on this, as well as a ton of time on the first COH.  So I know what I'm talking about.

If you like strategies for morons that involve no critical thinking or tactics, just blobbing and spamming, like Supreme Commander, this one's for you!

The cutting of tons of content and bundling in limitless packages is the most atrocious part.  Total greed.

reviewText:
For those who have played COH1 and are still on the fence about buying this game, this review is for you:

When I first purchased COH1, it was love at first sight. With 6 compelling campaigns and awesome mods and maps to play with after getting bored with the vanilla version, I got hooked real quick, I probably spent a good 200+ hours playing it off and on for the past 2 years.  The campaigns had the same feeling as the first 2 Call of Duties mixed with a hint of Band of Brothers.

Since I loved COH1 so much, I decided to disregard the enormous amount of negative reviews and get it anyways.

COH2 is originally set on the Eastern Front, which suffice to say is better than the Eastern Front mod for COH1 in so many ways. Mainly, I like COH2 more because it comes with a great campaign, and doesn't require you to force restart your OP PC every time you try to boot up a game.

That being said, the campaign storyline in COH2 was a little better than if you compared them side-by-side with any of the COH1 campaigns. It felt a little more cheesy and CoD-ish than Brothers In Arms: EiB, but the same general attitude was used with great effect and had me compelled to play through the entire campaign in one sitting.

Then there are of course the countless DLCs that come with this game. Mainly, most of these are microtransactions, where now instead of doctrines, there are commanders. As for the other, more formal DLCs, there are 3 more factions to choose from if you get them. Also Ardennes Assault brings a new kind of campaign that is extremely different from what you'd normally expect, It's sort of a Turn-Based strategy on top of the base game that plays differently each campaign, with special events" where you can unlock certain vehicles for certain companies throughout the game. And then there's also mission packs
date: which can provide you with maybe 30 more hours of fun.\n\nSo all in all
recommended: would I recommend this game? I personally would
hoursPlayed: but only if there is a really good sale on it. The microtransactions kind of turned me off
voteText: but it wasn't gamebreaking for me. The campaign is good too

reviewText: This game is by far the most played game in my steam library, and also probably my most played game, aside from World of Warcraft. First off, the campaign is a it unrealistic since the soviets in many cases where not that brutal to their own soldiers nor their own civilians, but aside from that i found it very entertaining and you get to see a lot of the famous battles on the Eastern front. The contols are pretty much your regular RTS-game so if you are familiar with the genre you won't have a hard time to get used to them. Now, the best of the game is in the multiplayer, where you can play as fout different armies if you whave the Western Front Armies expansion. All these armies are varied and in my opinon well balanced, which gives a very enjoyable and competetive gaming experiance. There is also lots of different commanders to choose from which gives you five special abilities which consists of everything from an airstike to a heavy tank. Buy this game if you like tactical RTS-games, you will not regret it.

reviewText:
The Process of Taking Cover Arguably the most important thing in any armed conflict is taking cover. How did a game that focuses on micromanaging troops in combat screw this up so badly?

1.  First you have to click on the unit. Sounds simple enough, but for some reason I had a lot of difficulty with this. For some reason, units would not always select / de-select on the first click, sometimes it took two clicks or box selecting the unit to do so. That is just unacceptable. It lead to a lot of wrong orders, wasted time, and deaths. How can a game that is two years old not have that figured out?

2.  Order the unit to take cover. The fact that I have to babysit each unit to order them to take cover blows my mind. How could they not code the most basic of human instincts of taking cover when being shot at? It would be one thing if the cover was far away, you did tell them to move to the open location, but if a stone wall is just 5 yards away and they are under machine gun fire, why do they wait for your command to take cover rather than just moving?

3  Now make sure they actually move. In addition to waiting for a command that should not need to be ordered, once it comes, they don't always follow it. Sometimes I had to repeat orders to take cover, not because they were being pinned down by supressing fire, but because they were so busy standing and shooting they ignored me.

3.  Once they actually move, make sure they take the correct positions. For some reason, my units loved to hop over and take cover" on the wrong side of the wall. W...t...f...? At first I thought I was clicking on the wrong side of the wall
date: but I was not. They take cover on the right side of the wall and then jump over to chase retreating units

reviewText:
The orignal CoH is a masterpiece of RTS design. No other game could reward players so thoroughly when they correctly anticipated an enemy's play. The sequel is almost the same, except where the original is sharp and pointed, everything in CoH2 is sort of fuzzy and mushy.

In the original, each army had a number of different ways to play, with commander trees there were distinct and powerful. An experienced player might see a Wehrmacht opponent use Propaganda War in the early game, and know they should expect a King Tiger in the late game and plan for it. Now that every army has almost a dozen possible commanders who all mix and match skills, not only does your commander choice feel less distinct, but it removes an element of strategy and counter play. Plus, you level up linearly instead of with branched trees, so that element of planning is also lost.

You can also customize armies with sort of achievement-based" unlocks
date: but they just add to the fuzziness. Does a 2% faster machine gun reload matter? I can't really tell. Would I notice if my enemy had that power? Doubtful. It seems like they wanted to make your army feel personal
recommended: but didn't want to have higher level players stomp all over newer ones because their army was objectively better. The result? More fuzziness and confusion.\n\nThere's also a lack of focus in some of the gameplay itself. Snipers used to be a counter to the units like mortars and machine guns because those squads were very small. But in CoH2
hoursPlayed: the Russian army mortar and MG squads are massive
voteText: so the sniper that would make quick work of them with a good player has a much
helpfulPercent: much higher chance of being caught before they make a dent in those support squads. CoH2 took a brilliant piece of counterplay and designed it straight out of the game.\n\nIn terms of visual fidelity
votesHelpful: the whole game looks either the same or worse compared to the original. But
votesTotal: the system demands seem much higher for no discenerable gain. You can still pay CoH on a pretty mediocre or aged machine
votesFunny: but CoH2 will choke computers that play Relic's own Dawn of War 2 without a hitch.\n\nI was really hoping that the British Forces pack would rekindle my interest in this game
commentsCount: but it's just more disappointment. I really like Relic and I wanted to like this."

reviewText:
You may remember I wrote an extremely critical review on this game's release back in 2013, where I criticized some of the game's design choices, bad netcode, and DLC that made it extremely unpleasant to play.

Going back to the game recently, it appears that at least the netcode issues have largely been resolved so (yay Relic!) on that part. A lot of my criticisms of the original release have by and large been resolved, though I will still point out some problems in the game.

The publishers have taken the action of raising DLC prices on their in-game Store during major sales while giving discounts to make it seem as though you are receiving discounts off the item, which is not true as it is not only unethical and anti-consumer, but is also illegal in many regions. Should I also point to the fact that there are some fairly important bugs that were only uncovered recently despite the game having been released for quite a few years now (one being veterancy gained for reinforced squads).

DLC I think is still a major issue for the game, but SEGA being SEGA... Some of the DLC do affect gameplay ever so slightly which can be fairly annoying if you're just starting out and don't want to spend money on the commanders.

Last but not least, I'm happy they launched the game on Linux and Mac (though not too glad the multiplayer isn't cross-platform between Windows and the other two versions - explanation from Feral here). Hence, I maintain my stance giving this game a negative review.

reviewText:
I feel a bit of resentment playing this game. First off, because I really enjoyed CoH 1, and in my honest opinion, I feel this game is robbed from what made CoH such a great game. The doctrine trees, the unit models and the realism, of course it might just be me wanting to actually see the soldiers getting blown to pieces by an artillery shell. Anyway this game feels different.. It does not make me feel like I play a Company Of Heroes game other than in name.
The MP changes to a more comptetetive system is a great improvement, so is the difficulity in personallizing your own army, by choosing different traits or specs. It makes the game more difficult, but at the same time I feel it has lost it values.

I'm not even going to get started on the market strategy that has been used here, because these DLC's are just moneygrinding. If they had done like they did with Opposing Front and Tales of Valor it would be just ok. As those games were cheap expansion, giving a great game content, to a good price. Now it has turned towards EA style money grabbing.

I don't know if anyone agrees with me - or totally disagree. I just wanted to push forward my opinion. As I was really really excited when they announced this game, but when it came I got so disappointed. 17 hours was all I played, but the release of the British Army might turn that around.

From a grumpy disappointed Stannis The Mannis.

reviewText:
Company of Heroes 2 is a real-time strategy developed by Relic Entertainment and published by SEGA. It is a sequel to Company of Heroes.

Company of Heroes 2, has many good improvements, but also many downside. Let's start with the good thing. Company of Heroes 2 new features include new faction, new off map unit spawn, better graphics, the new Theater of War mode and more. Gameplay is absolutely better, points can now be captured just by standing inside the capture zone so infantry can focus on shooting the enemy, infantry can also now climb fences or something like that, vehicles can be abandoned when badly damaged, so we can capture and repair enemy vehicles. There is also new commander and doctrine system which make the gameplay even more vary. Modding support are also better especially with the new Steam Workshop integration. There are more to see and you will be pleased to see them.

Graphics of Company of Heroes 2 are better than the first game, quite the improvements and I gotta say it's beautiful. The explosion effects, the textures variable, snow effects and stuff. It's great. They has the new snow blizzard effect that also affect gameplay, in skirmish games on snow maps blizzard can randomly happen, entirely changing the situation. Units are even more detailed with many new animations and skins for vehicles. At release and some time after that, the performance of the game was very terrible. But now finally Relic has updated the game and the performance are far more better than before, at least maybe it's because the cap it at 30 fps.

But not everything in this sequel are great. Bad things also present in this Company of Heroes 2. The campaign story. I don't know, I don't want to spoil it, but there are some things considered... what, inappropriate? Like did the old Soviet Union shoots their own soldiers or executing them for heroic act like saving their Captain who was in trouble?

Well, overall, for the base game and expansion packs, I recommend this game, because it's good sequel.

Rating 8/10

reviewText:
If you are looking for the best strategy game out there then consider buying this game.

It strikes the perfect balance between number of units / micro-management / flank-rear-front positioning / tactical usage / occasional massing / using cover / unit abilties / resource management /choke-point control / etc

It isn't overly crowded like Age of Empires or similar games
But you have control of more than 1 or 2 single units.

In an average game you are probably simultaneously trying to control 5 or 6 different units in pretty crucial micro-management situations. While this is quite difficult to master, it is extremely rewarding.

For example:
While you are simultaneously turning your machine-gun around to face a flank attack, you need to dodge the enemy grenade with your forward infantry, cancel your mortar attack, re-direct your AT, create a new squad of troops, and release covering smoke from your tank.
-You will eventually get used to the intense micromanaging pace this game sets.
It is absolutely amazing.

+ Unlike other strategy games a soldier firing a rifle at a tank doesn't do any damage. Yes, absolutely zero damage. Which is reassuring to say the least.

reviewText:
A well made game, although it has a large quantity of DLC and some of it is questionably priced most of it can be acquired by playing the game, although the drops system is very bad and you will need to play a lot to maybe get the drop you want. This game has an immense variety of ways to play from the campaigns, to theatre of war, to competitive multiplayer. You can also experiment on different maps with different commanders which allow for different styles of play, and If you get bored of the default maps you can always go on the workshop and choose from an almost endless variety of maps, mods, and win conditions. The amount of content in this game is huge compared to other RTS games.

I highly suggest playing this game over voice chat with friends if you plan on doing multplayer (Automatch vs Players).
There is nothing more satisfying than coordinating a strategy with your teammates and watching it play out flawlessly.
voteText: 21 of 38 people (55%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Building upon their greatest work, Company of Heroes 1, Relic created a masterpiece we now call Company of Heroes 2.

Company of Heroes 2 is by far the greatest strategy game I've ever played. The graphics are intensely beautiful when put to Maximum Settings. The explosions look realistic and captivating. The armor of all the units look very authentic. The maps have beautiful textures. Just like how Company of Heroes 1 was marvelous to the eye, Company of Heroes 2 provides the same role as one of the best looking Strategy games out there.

First of all, you need to give Relic slack for even making a sequel to their videogame. These guys were completely bankrupt by THQ, who sold them to Sega. Relic suffered through some serious financial problems, but loe and behold, they had the heart to make the next greatest game. They couldn't do everything they wanted to do, nor did they have the funds to tweak the game to the point where the community wouldn't be upset. So please, if you feel that the game is rusty, give them some time.

By now, if you're reading this. The game is already near perfection. The old days of overpowered units are over, and Relic is continuously, month after month, providing game changing balance tweaks and completely new content. I anticipate every month that they provide us with whole new maps, new units, new commanders, and balance tweaks.

If you guys got bored of this game in the past, please give it another shot. And for the people who are skeptical about buying this game, this game is totally worth it!

It's Relic, they made arguably the greatest strategy game of all time, and they are bound to do it again!

And by the way... Metascore lies. That 80 point Metascore only considers Company of Heroes 2 at day 1 of release, not where it is now. It is a completely different game from what it used to be.

reviewText:
Well to summarise the history:  It is 1941 and the beginning of what will become the most brutal conflict of World War II, as Germany launches a full-scale invasion of the frozen tundra of the Soviet Union which would result in over 14 million military casualties.

Now you know all the historical details, you follow Lev Abramovich Isakovich (Yes, his name is Abramovich Isakovich, kinda like calling an American Kid, Johnny Doucebag) a Soviet Army lieutenant locked up at a gulag in Siberia in 1952. An Army colonel – his old commanding officer – interrogates him about his experiences during the war.

Now onto the gameplay...
This game does have repetitive features from the original Company of Heroes BUT, it also adds alot of new features as well, for example the addition of your men freezing to death if you don't make them go near a campfire or shelter for too long. Firefights in the game do get rather intense but as I said, quite repetitive from the original COH.

Soldier: Comrades we must push forward through the blizzard because our Commander forced us to, it's for the best tovarisch. URA!

Yeah sure the new features are new and creative, however the thing that bugged me was some of the missions were...unorthadox. Like burning Russian villages with RUSSIANS INSIDE THEM.

Soldier: HAHA, BURN, BURN FASCIST PIGS! HAHAHAHHA....Hehe....Eeeehhh sh*t.

I'm not sure where Relic gets these 'historical facts' from, but it sounds like they pulled it out of their asses.

Lets not forget the beginning of the game during the tutorial mission, where at the end you're shown a cinematic of a Russian commander ordering a machinegunner to execute retreating Russian soldiers.

Clap Clap Clap Clap

Geez, you could've jsut sacked them or make them go into disciplinary action. But yeah you could just do this:

https://i.gyazo.com/b7b2da0279b6d544af17a60f86acaa3e.gif



Now the part that everyone loves, the ☭ Final Verdict ☭

Apart from all the repetitive features that Relic just happened to slap on and call it a new one.
Company of Heroes 2 does not lose its touch on fun RTS and commanding forces from either Allied or Axis troops.

Positives:
+Intense firefights
+Excellent storyline
+Graphics are decent (depending on what computer you have)
+Adds new features that the original lacked

Negatives:
-Repetitive features from the original COH
-Adds a bunch of DLC packs which are almost worthless
-Great History .-.

I rate this game a 7/10
It's an OK RTS game, however as I said, unorthadox.

reviewText: If you like playing these kind of games and you like WW2, then this is a must buy game. I would recommand to buy it on sale since it's a few years old, but I would definitely buy it full price even in 2016. Amazing game. Great campaign mode, CoH part one already has an awsome campaign and CoH2 follows in those footsteps. The game is graphic a lot better than part one, also there are a lot more units. Multiplayer is also awsome, really fun. You have to constantly capture and secure points, the balance of battle can shift a lot in one single game. That keeps it always interesting if you play AI (apart from easy) or players of your own caliber. You have to micromanage a lot of units, that can be a bit difficult at first but you will get use to that pretty soon. I would suggest buying a clompete pack, so you can play all factions in multiplayer mode.

reviewText:
Lovely looking game. SOME good mechanics.
At release, wasn't balanced, now it depends on how much $ you will fork over.
Commanders are 4 bucks a pop, and a set for ONE OF THE FIVE factions is ~60.

I will not buy another game from relic because of this. Sure I have a plenty of hours, mainly in attempt for my money to feel validated. It doesn't. Buy one of the many other WWII RTS out there and you will be a much happy camper.
And maybe this is why nobody respects SEGA.

reviewText:
Company of Heroes 2 is just as great as CoH1, even better, I can't find that much negative to say about the game, only positive stuff. Great game, Great moments, Great community. Has one of the best campaigns I've played, minus two of the missions which aren't my type of mission. Stealth and Strategy doesnt go hand in hand. It does put both sides (axis and allies) in a bad light, but it's war, both sides did terrible stuff. But it also shows heroes, and you create the heroes in the campaign, why else would you have to capture a tiger tank with infantry?

TOW (Theater of War) is also a great new thing for the game, and really adds to the CO-OP side of the game. some missions even allow 3vsAI which is cool. TOW also lets you play on both sides (DLC doesnt, Case Blue is german side while Victory at Stalingrad is Soviet) So you can say there is a german campaign aswell, and it can be played in coop mode.

MP (Multiplayer) is also quite fun, I havent played much multiplayer myself, but playing with friends against the AI is so much fun, and that is what have kept me playing.
the DLC is great, despite some of it being overpriced its worth it. And thank you Relic for sometimes giving the community some free DLC.

TWFA (The Western Front Armies)
Is also great, even though I've only spend about 10 hours I can already say that the expansion is worth the money. The Oberkommando West is not like the other factions and really shows germany's economy problems at the end of 1944 with high priced vehicles, and resources being more valuable, but also gives us some of the heavy armor we've all been waiting for in a game, who would of have thought that we would see a Halftrack with infrared lights?

The U.S Forces are great too! really gives us some new toys, That we didn't see in the first game, and the ability to de-crew vehicles on command, that really leads to some interesting tactics, the downside is playing with the AI and seeing it steal your decrewed vehicle... Maybe you shouldnt let the AI get too close with their own vehicle crews?

AA (Ardennes Assault)
Dont' buy this campaign if you're not a SP player or intend to only play it once.
The campaign itself is broing, not much of a challenge. There is no strategy to the metamap. All you have to do is walk around the map with any company and win the mission. It doesnt matter whether your company is cut off or anything, you can do as you please. The enemy does also not get any penalties once you cut them from a supply line. The missions themselves are also not that great, most of them are regular Victory Point games, so just go play skirmish as USF? They try to make these missions more interesting by adding in special handicaps, so you can be so unlocky you have to wait for 5 minutes for resources, again boring. The descriptions of the missions are also very misleading, they make the mission look way harder than they are. They do also make it look like some of the missions are timed, eventhough they aren't. You can play the campaign three times, if you have all 4 companies, before you'll start to find it very boring.

The downside of the game is the war spoils (something like that), it works like the Team Fortress 2 drop system, only worse, I guess its bugged. But other than that its a great game, great graphics and great performance, mostly, sometimes delays appear when giving a unit an order.
voteText: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful

reviewText: This game has the steepest learning curve in recent memory. I've played tons of rts games including many hours on the original Company of Heroes and this game's difficulty is by far the hardest of any that I've played. On Normal difficulty (the one I'm assuming that most people will start on) the difficulty is far beyond that of any rts I can think of, this isn't a criticism of the gameplay mechanics or the AI's intelligence both of which are very good, the normal AI is simply too hard for most people who'd be new to the game or even those who are experienced in the genre. The AI even on normal is ruthless and plays with a remarkable degree of skill and utilisation of the game elements, often flanking, providing diversions and usings all elements of the game mechanics, and while this is a great display of the game's AI most players aren't going to be good enough to face off against the normal AI for sometime. While some people might say play the Easy AI instead then move up"
date: this isn't a viable option as the easy AI is borderline braindead
recommended: providing little to no challenge what so ever
hoursPlayed: and I'd imagine that people would learn little from playing against it for prolonged periods of time. To make myself clear

reviewText: I wish I hadn't spent money on this game. The overall feel is not that smooth, and it's extremely difficult to do two things at once. You wanna command a line of infantry in combat, but they need reinforcements? There's no easy access to reinforcements, no, you're going to have to abandon your troops and go back to your base to call them in. Adding in that the maximum outward zoom is only a few meters, this can take a while.\n\nOverall, the game has all the right elements for a strategy game, but doesn't understand how to make an interface for a strategy game. I'll stick with Sins of a Solar Empire for my RTS.

reviewText:
Pros:

1.  Exceptional graphics (I play on ultra quality) among almost all other WWII RTS on the market.
2.  Drop of Goodies (not frequently but truly free) after sometime.
3.  Realistic uniforms, tanks, planes along with historically coherent campaign
4.  Strong community support (free maps, mods, skins for download from Modding Hub)
5.  Every match is a unique one, every general is a unique one, everyone has a choice of their way to play

Cons:

Price is expensive?            (wait for a promotional sale event, the ingame goodies are free and will drop from air)

Balancing issues?              (all units can be countered by another unit,  skill matters over trivial complain on balance)

Server issues?                    (seems to be it depends on the host's PC power, update comes once 3 months to address issues)

This is a review from an experienced RTS player. (StarCraft 2, Sins of a Solar Empire, Age of Empires 3 Collection, Command and Conquer Ultimate Collection)

If you love strategy and team work,  this is one of the finest WWII RTS ever made!

reviewText:
is this a bad game?...no
is this a good game?..no
is it worth a £30 price tag then extra for some DLC that should really have been released as part of the game?...no chance, if you see it for £10-£15 then it's fine

it's ok, campaign is decent enough but the MP maps are all pretty much the same and the enemy AI is clearly able to see every move you make from start to finish, this will no doubt be to increase difficulty but all it actually does is make it frustrating and utterly pointless setting up any kind of meaningful defences (a play style i enjoy is defend to build strength then hit back)

Russians can gank infantry and tanks very fast and very early on in the game leaving Germans on the defensive

Germans if lucky enough to hold out long enough to build Panther tanks then through in some carefull control of them along with engineers for repairs and two or three anti infantry vehicles/units and the tables switch pretty fast

all in all not bad but nothing special either, if you cant find it on offer dont worry just buy the entire CoH1 pack for less and get far more out of it

If you are interested in getting into CoH then I would highly recommend looking into CoH 1 with all the expansions.\n\nHint: just look at the metascores they gave CoH 1 and 2. reviewText:
There is a huge difference between admitting war crimes as a nation and doing Relic's job. In the first case, everything that was wrong with USSR was admitted by Russians in an awful lot of books and studies. It's all up for you to read. Largely explained, with many photos of those times. If you wish to explore it quicker, you can watch some documentaries on this topic. Most of which are made by Russians, by the way. Nobody else is as interested in rooting into WW2 as Russian people. This war took a lot of their lives. They took the hardest punch, went through it hand to hand with Allies and regular people, like you and me. Everyone was united by a cause Germans would never figure out. To defend their kind. Germans had a little..different ideals.

What Relic did with Company of Heroes 2 is called defamation.

Being Polish, you should probably know the term very well. (referring the guy in the comments section)

So what Relic does is not only show us the 'dark face' as you might say, but instead of making an incredible story of a horrible event they make a propaganda-fueled movie in style of US movies of 1960. The 'bad commie' type of film.

There is a huge difference between narrated storytelling based on proven facts with a huge pile of evidence, and making this crap.

I love history. I love reading books, finding rare videos of those times, looking at old and exquisite photographs that might seem uninteresting to most people. Photos of regular people standing united by a cause. And no, I don't mean Nazis in this case. I'd say they were more divided in ideology than anyone.

But I hate it when people who can manipulate masses blow the only thing they were supposed to do - tell the facts, and make them seem real. The drama, the horror of World War 2 should be in place. A mother burrying her own son, a man dying on arms of his fellow friends, children preparing for what they are going to face, people hearing the sirens, looking at the skies and knowing what is going to follow. All of this should be put in place.

The war was fought by the real people. The real people died in this war, not those plastic figures for whom the only reason to fight is so they won't be punished by the command.
(As shown by Relic)

Popular magazines who reviewed the game with scores of 8 and higher were probably paid to skip the campaign and rate multiplayer only, which didn't change much. I love the snow blizzard, but that's it. New units and tons of paid DLCs don't make a game. Well they didn't some time ago, now it's considered a really nice effort.

Unfortunately, German propaganda worked too well, as Werner Naumann pointed out. It ricocheted against their own people, made their troops lose the war, but it works pretty well nowadays. For the most of people, that is. Like the Polish guy from comments below. Too many people are sheep who don't believe in things other than 'bad' or 'good'.

When people grow up they start wondering if there is really black and white, or is there something beyond? If the time isn't right for you, if you just stopped playing Call of Duty with your 12-year-old fifth grade classmates, buy this game and enjoy the campaign to the fullest. You'll love it.

reviewText:
I played thousands of hours in COH one and I had high hopes for COH2. Having played some games in COH2 now, with regret, and no little disappointment - I find I hate this. Utterly spolied by the brilliance of COH1 and add ons and mods, I go in here, and find some cartoony version. The bleak eastern front is some disney coloured horror. The game for starters is too damn zoomed in. It needs at least an ability to zoom 30% more out from the battle field.

They clearly kept too much Dawn of war involvement in this production. The game needs severe toning down on the silly over use of cartoon like colour. A better zoom. Even with this, so far, I've just not enjoyed it. I'll try some more, but everything is pop ups, and garish colours, and its missing a lot of feel from COH. Even the simple stuff like the map in the left bottom corner is just worse than COH, with more difficulty in simply map marking and so on.

If you have none of these, really consider getting COH 1 and its add ons. I can't recommend COH2 at this time..

reviewText: I'm not recommending this game for most players, but for RTS gamers who love the WW2 genre sure go ahead.  COH1 is still a far better game with regards to gameplay, balance, and personally I would also say graphics.  Yes COH2 has more map detail but big deal, it only slows down the already sluggish gameplay.  COH2 is stacked very heavily towards the germans, and you see this by the number of players who play axis VS allies in MP.  I typically play the soviets for something different, but it's frustrating while battling OP stacked german teams.  Also for those that complain about DLC, you don't need upgrades to win, but for a game that's already poorly balanced its one more thing that can tip the scales in favor of the other team.

reviewText: Took me a bit to get into this game coming from being such a huge Company of Heroes one fan, but once I got the hang of it and they got some of the balance and bugs worked out, this game has proven to be a very enjoyable experience. The graphics are very detailed, the sound is excellent, the combat intense and the strategies required to win are never set in stone. It is a difficult game to fully grasp if you've no experience with an RTS like it, but features like destructible environments, cover, dynamic line of sight, and even things like armor facing make this an incredibly unique RTS with no equal.\n\nDon't expect this game to go easy on you - every little second and ability counts just as much as the units you pit against your enemy and your strategy on how to combat them. You must be able to multitask and micromanage very well all while understanding the dynamics between each unit. This is a game that is all about how you are able to deal with the cards you are dealt, not the kind of deck you build before the fight. In other words, its not so much about build order and timing as it is about positioning, reconnaissance, micromanagement, reactions, and being able to think on your feet. If that sounds like an interesting challenge to you, then I HIGHLY reccomend this game.

reviewText:
A game that requires true strategy and tactics to allow you to hold the banner of victory over your people's heads. I have played over 100 hours of this game offline (it may say that I have only played 5 hours but that isnt true) and I have enjoyed every minute of it! Just watch out when playing as any faction other than the Oberkommando West, they will destroy you with the Sturmtiger tank and absolutely obliterate your forces and your soldiers & tanks can do almost no damage to them. You need the strategy of a general to win this game which brings out the what the game is extremely well.

Did I mention that battle tactics such as General Zhukov's pincer attack can be useful in this game? Well the amazing thing about this game is just that, not to mention countless hours of fun against an AI that you can totally overpower or online against 7 other people that stand no chance against your mighty tanks and infanrty.

2000/10 for this game!

reviewText: I played the first part already thousands of hours as I played both Dawn of War games. As with the other relic games, I only bought it because of the multiplayer, never tried the singleplayer, and was always a great fan of relic games. They always were my bread and butter. Problem with this game is the balancing and I'm not talking of the balance between factions - they are currently almost equally strong - but the balance between different kinds of units. In the current version infantry and medium tanks are way overpowered, so everybody is just spamming infantry and medium tanks. Most units became useless and are rarely used and everybody plays the same strategies. You will see blobs in every game. Its only about blobs, takes all the fun out for me. People mass riflemen, volks etc until they have a massive blob, then late game they spam shermans, t34/85 etc. 90% of americans play the same commander to spam E8. With commanders it's the same as with units, everybody plays the same few commanders all the time, most are never used, because they are unbalanced. I can't blame the players, the game forces you to spam and rewards spamming. If you don't adapt and abuse the same ♥♥♥♥ you will have a hard time, makes the game very repetetive. I enjoyed their previous games especially because you had to mix many different unit types to be succesful and it enabled many different strategies, but in CoH 2 there are only very few possible army compositions if you want to play effective. I had a lot of patience (as you can see I played over 1000h), because I understand that balancing is a difficult issue, but balance will never get fixed, it rather gets worse. They keep adding more factions and commanders and apparently that makes it too difficult to balance the game. On top of that the new warspoil system is totally ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and SEGA is milking customers with DLC in a very obscene manner. The community is also very immature and consists mainly of people who blame their allies, bugs and luck if they loose - crying, raging and dropping - but offend you in ridiculous ways if they manage to win. All that totally destroys this game, which could have been a great experience.

reviewText:
I find this game difficult to recommend. Not because it's bad, that's certainly not the case! It's actually very enjoyable. My gripe with it is that, in almost every aspect, it pales in comparison to its predecessor. Company of Heroes 1 is still a fantastic game, one with (arguably) more content and better balance. It's also much, much cheaper than this sequel.

Company of Heroes 2 has some interesting additions to the incredible RTS formula Relic have forged. Cold weather means warmth is a new resource to be considered, frozen lakes crack under bombardment, and units are slowed during blizzards. Slight changes have been made to unit control, too, so now players can vault soldiers over cover, and split and merge squads at their will. These new elements are fun, but ultimately don't add a whole lot to the game. The same can be said for the new maps. I honestly find myself enjoying the selection of battlegrounds included from the original more than the new content. They don't have the same edge, and really, that can be said for the entire game.

Players new to the franchise will likely have a great time playing this game. Returning players may find themselves a little bit disappointed. Regardless, Company of Heroes 2 is a solid game, I won't deny that. I would just encourage anyone who reads this to opt for the original with its expansions.

I find this game difficult to recommend. Not because it's bad, that's certainly not the case! It's actually very enjoyable. My gripe with it is that, in almost every aspect, it pales in comparison to its predecessor. Company of Heroes 1 is still a fantastic game, one with (arguably) more content and better balance. reviewText:
Despite loving the original Company of Heroes games, I feel like this game is made purely to make money.

Without buying the numerous DLC you are severely limited to what you can play - campaigns are even off limits until you buy them separately. This makes the game unplayable - it leads you on to think that you are able to play a certain mission, and at the last possible point will inform you that you need to buy it.

Quite frankly, unless you're willing to spend atrocious amounts of money on this game, it isn't worth it.

reviewText:
COH2 is a bittersweet affair.

The base game and gameplay is excellent; it is an improved version of COH's wonderful squad based tactics and vehicle combat, but it's split up into as many parts as SEGA could get Relic to create. COH simply had 2 expansions, Opposing Fronts and Tales of Valor which your could have bought with the base game for $100 MSRP, at release.

COH2 has no less than 6, as well as dozens of DLC commanders and skins. The base game with minor expansions cost around $140, and the commanders would cost you nearly as much if you wanted them all. The skins I can forgive as they are cosmetic, but the commanders introduce new units and capabilities that ABSOLUTELY RUIN THE MULTIPLAYER.

Take the Soviet Industry Tactics commander for instance, that gives you the capability to slam out T-70s and T-34s out so quick, the enemy barely has time to deploy AT guns. Or the Elite Troops Doctrine, that allows you to pay for veterancy in troops, as well as a Tiger Ace. Do you want the have the ability to use this against your opponents? You've got to pay extra, of course!

This simply is unnacceptable, and I can't recommend anyone pay for such a shameful pay-2-win scheme.

Now, with my gripe out of the way;

COH2 has a great Soviet single player campaign, and the Ardennes Assault campaign is fun, although it has less personality being somewhat more freeform. I enjoyed all the missions from Case Blue, but haven't tried Victory at Stalingrad or Southern Fronts.

I really, really, really wish they'd had a German compaign like in COH's Opposing Fronts. It was a favorite of mine, as well as the British Campaign. The fact that COH2 doesn't have anything more than a Soviet Campaign and American campaign in the style of Warhammer DOW Black Crusade is dissapointing. The Brits, Ostheer and Oberkommado West are completely left behind.

As for the multiplayer, it's solid and fun. It allows for only 2 game modes, Victory Points and Annihilation, but games are typically fierce and fair. As long as you can ignore the unfair DLC commanders, you'll enjoy it.

Overall, COH2 is a great game, but flawed by SEGA, an evil DLC loving publisher. It makes me sad that Relic fell under their corrupting and vile influence, but at least their games are still mostly intact. Without the disgusting DLC commanders, I'd give the game a 8.5-9.0 out of 10. However, with the current dispicable DLC situation, it's only a 7.5. Still a recommended game, and one of the best of the modern RTS games, but dissapointing for afformentioned reasons.

reviewText:
Why you should get this game
It is an awesome WWII RTS with a lot taken from their earlier games like COH and Dawn Of War. The cover mechanic and how you need to use AT weapons against armored targets to be able to take them down is awesome! Play the pretty OKAY campaign with terrible voiceacting and do some skirmishes against the AI and your friends.
With five diffrent armies with diffrent playstyles, you will surely find one that suits you and your style.

Not a campaign or skirmish fan? Well then you're in luck my friend. There is a type of challenge mode in this game called the Theatre of War" which is basicly recycled maps from the skirmish with diffrent objectives to fullfill apart from destroying your enemies base or capturing points.

Why you should NOT get this game
Like multiplayer? Like to play ranked? Want to take your army and battle it out all over the world against players thirsting for a fight? Yeah? Well you'll not find what you're looking for in this game.

Why? Because the "Elo+" ranking system is ♥♥♥♥ed beyond repair in this one

TL'DR
Relic needs to fix the matchmaking for the multiplayer to be enjoyable as a solo player. Other than that

reviewText:
A sequeal that looks to outshine its predecessor, but fails short on a few parts. The first Company of Heroes hooked my brother and I on it like crazy. We played hours and hours of it, against each other and AI. We would attempt to recreate scenarios in that game, and we simply loved it. When we heard it will be getting a 2 added to it's title, we freaked out.

Too bad, it didn't achieve what we would have liked from it. They added the British and American armies a bit too late into the game's cycle, and changed concepts, that while new, were simply fine the way they were in the first COH.

It's still a fun game, but lacks the fun the first gave.

reviewText:
COH2 is a bittersweet affair.

The base game and gameplay is excellent; it is an improved version of COH's wonderful squad based tactics and vehicle combat, but it's split up into as many parts as SEGA could get Relic to create. COH simply had 2 expansions, Opposing Fronts and Tales of Valor which your could have bought with the base game for $100 MSRP, at release.

COH2 has no less than 6, as well as dozens of DLC commanders and skins. The base game with minor expansions cost around $140, and the commanders would cost you nearly as much if you wanted them all. The skins I can forgive as they are cosmetic, but the commanders introduce new units and capabilities that ABSOLUTELY RUIN THE MULTIPLAYER.

Take the Soviet Industry Tactics commander for instance, that gives you the capability to slam out T-70s and T-34s out so quick, the enemy barely has time to deploy AT guns. Or the Elite Troops Doctrine, that allows you to pay for veterancy in troops, as well as a Tiger Ace. Do you want the have the ability to use this against your opponents? You've got to pay extra, of course!

This simply is unnacceptable, and I can't recommend anyone pay for such a shameful pay-2-win scheme.

Now, with my gripe out of the way;

COH2 has a great Soviet single player campaign, and the Ardennes Assault campaign is fun, although it has less personality being somewhat more freeform. I enjoyed all the missions from Case Blue, but haven't tried Victory at Stalingrad or Southern Fronts.

I really, really, really wish they'd had a German compaign like in COH's Opposing Fronts. It was a favorite of mine, as well as the British Campaign. The fact that COH2 doesn't have anything more than a Soviet Campaign and American campaign in the style of Warhammer DOW Black Crusade is dissapointing. The Brits, Ostheer and Oberkommado West are completely left behind.

As for the multiplayer, it's solid and fun. It allows for only 2 game modes, Victory Points and Annihilation, but games are typically fierce and fair. As long as you can ignore the unfair DLC commanders, you'll enjoy it.

Overall, COH2 is a great game, but flawed by SEGA, an evil DLC loving publisher. It makes me sad that Relic fell under their corrupting and vile influence, but at least their games are still mostly intact. Without the disgusting DLC commanders, I'd give the game a 8.5-9.0 out of 10. However, with the current dispicable DLC situation, it's only a 7.5. Still a recommended game, and one of the best of the modern RTS games, but dissapointing for afformentioned reasons.

reviewText:
Why you should get this game
It is an awesome WWII RTS with a lot taken from their earlier games like COH and Dawn Of War. The cover mechanic and how you need to use AT weapons against armored targets to be able to take them down is awesome! Play the pretty OKAY campaign with terrible voiceacting and do some skirmishes against the AI and your friends.
With five diffrent armies with diffrent playstyles, you will surely find one that suits you and your style.

Not a campaign or skirmish fan? Well then you're in luck my friend. There is a type of challenge mode in this game called the Theatre of War" which is basicly recycled maps from the skirmish with diffrent objectives to fullfill apart from destroying your enemies base or capturing points.

Why you should NOT get this game
Like multiplayer? Like to play ranked? Want to take your army and battle it out all over the world against players thirsting for a fight? Yeah? Well you'll not find what you're looking for in this game.

Why? Because the "Elo+" ranking system is ♥♥♥♥ed beyond repair in this one

reviewText:
EXPLAINING MYSELF
Before I start my review,I will say that I played the first Company of Heroes with all its expansion packs(Opposing Fronts and Tales of Valor) and that I had a rather enjoyable experience.The factions were diverse and unique and the campaign had some challenge in it.The multiplayer was the epitome of multiplayer strategy.

ONE OF THESE THINGS IS NOT LIKE THE OTHER
So,what does Company of Heroes 2 offer that its predecessor doesn't?Well,the setting is different.Eastern front in the center of the game,therefore Ostheer(East German army) and the Soviet Red Army are the available factions to play as.The Germans have smaller squads but are generally superior in equipment and training(e.g.the Panzergrenadiers can be upgraded with Panzershreck to eliminate armor,none of the Soviet infantry has any upgrade to do so).The Soviets have larger squads,which gives them better chances to survive and reinforce(except the Engineers who have 4 and Sniper team who has 2,the rest of the Soviet squads have 6 men).

NICE,BUT HOW DO YOU PLAY IT?
The gameplay is the same as in the last game;capture point to get resorces and don't let the territories get cut off from your main base.However,instead of some points offering munitions,fuel or manpower, most points offer both munitions and fuel(in a smaller amount) with some offering just fuel or munitions but in a higher amount.Those that offer both may be secured to either increase their munitions or fuel output(but not both).Tactics such as taking cover,flanking,suppressing and vehicle positioning are important to win battles,since a heavy tank can be defeated if engaged with a AT gun while the bazooka team flanks and attacks his weak back armor.Overall,it's the same game,but...

LET IT SNOW
The snow ain't just for aesthetic purposes.Heavy snow can slow down both infantry and vehicles,and in some situations your men will freeze to death if they are not in a building,vehicle or near a fireplace.Blizzarrds may occur at random(you will get a warning and a timer telling you how much is left before it hits).It lowers the sight range of all your units,while freezing the men,forcing you to take care of them.Vehicles and men leave marks on the snow so you know if someone passed there and where he went.

YURI,WHAT DO YOUR BLUE EYES SEE?
Tue line of sight is implemented in this game.In simple terms,your units cannot see behind walls or through trees,making ambushes a potent tactical solution(the first game didn't have true line of sight).It is a very fun mechanic that I haven't seen since the games of Stormregion(Codename:Panzers and Rush for Berlin).It makes scouting a neccessary maneuver to your strategy and smoke screens a life saver from artillery and machineguns(my Soviet Shock troops saved a lot of my men with their smoke grenades).An excellent addition to the game.LOVE IT!

WANT TO GO TO A THEATER?
Theater of War is and addition to the singleplayer portion of the game.You have solo challenges and coop scenarios.These can vary from officer assasination,holding a position,eliminating a armoured column during the blizzard and so on.It extends the life of the game and if you have a friend,some of the scenarios you can play with him.

COMPANY OF FUN
The multiplayer is so fun I don't know what words to use.It's immersive and action packed,but smart action.You need to make decisions fast and smart to win.The user interface really helps here;on the bottor right you can select the production buildings,set a rally point and order a unit to arrive.this is important in the early stages of the game,when deployment to the frontline is crucial.The various maps also help in this,considering that they are different in sizer and terrain.

SINGLE IS COLD
I played the first three missions of the campaign and didn't continue because I ran out of time(I played this during the free weekend action).The campaign is inferior to that from CoH1.Whil CoH1 displayed the Americans,British and Germans as normal people doing their duty,the Soviet army men are portrayed as cowards who shoot their own men in the back.True,attrocities were made by the Red Army and the methods they used were brutal,but htere must have been some heroic moments.Sadly,the campaign doesn't show that,and the way the story is presented doesn't help.It is told via a flashback,which makes it feel detached from reality.Add in that the focus is on the bad side of the Red Army(and that the Germans are nothing more than obstacle,rather that a force),while showing nothing bad about the German army(they did attrocities,no army is safe from that) adn you get and rather empty and almost surreal story that is hard to believe or take serious.

COMRADE,WHAT IS THE CONCLUSION?
Company of Heroes 2 is an excellent strategy with excellent multiplayed balancing,a sizeable singleplayer content and a dull campaign story.If you're buying it for the multiplayer,you won't be dissapointed.If you're buying it for the challenges,missions and scenarios in th Theater of War you will get a kick from it.If you're buying it for and interesting story then you will get dissapointed with it.
